DIV1.P: OR, When Women goe to Law, the Deuill is full of Businesse.
A new Tragecomaedy. The true and perfect Copie from the Originall. As it was approouedly well Acted by her Maiesties Seruants.
DIV1.Q: Non quam diu, sed quam bene.
DIV1.P: LONDON, Printed by A. M. for Iohn Grismand, and are to be sold at his Shop in Pauls Alley at the Signe of the Gunne. 1623.

DIV1.HEAD: TO THE RIGHT VVOR THIE, AND All-accomplisht Gentleman, Sir THOMAS FINCH, Knight BARONET.
DIV1.P: SIR, let it not appeare strange, that I doe aspire to your Patronage. Things that taste of any goodnesse, loue to bee shel∣ter'd neere Goodnesse: Nor do I slatter in this (which I hate) onely touch at the originall Copy of your vertues. Some of my other Works, as The white Deuill, The Dutchesse of Malfi, Guise, and others, you haue formerly seene; I present this hum∣bly to kisse your hands, and to find your allowance. Nor doe I much doubt it, knowing the greatest of the Caesars, haue cheerefully entertain'd lesse Poems then this: and had I thought it vnworthy, I had not enquired after so worthy a Patronage. Your selfe I vnderstand, to bee all curtesie. I doubt not there∣fore of your acceptance, but resolue, that my electi∣on is happie. For which fauour done mee, I shall euer rest

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your Worships humbly deuoted, IOHN WEBSTER.

DIV1.HEAD: TO THE IVDITIOVS READER.
DIV1.P: I Hold it, in these kind of Poems with that of Horace, Sapntia prima, stultitia caruisle; to bee free from those vices, which proceed from ignorance; of which I take it, this Play will ingeniously acquit it selfe. I doe chly therefore ex∣pose t to the Iudicious: Locus est, & pluribus Vmbis, oth haue leaue to sit downe, and reade it, who come vn∣bidden. But to these, should a man present them with the most excellent Musicke, it would delight them no more, then Auriculas Citherae collecta sorde dolen∣tes. I will not further insist vpon the approouement of it, for I am so farre from praising my selfe, that I haue not giuen way to diuers of my Friends, whose vnbeg'd Commendatory Verses offered themselues to doe me ser∣uice in the Front of this Poeme. A great part of the grace of this (I confesse) lay in Action; yet can no Action euer be gracious, where the decency of the Language, and Ingenious structure of the Scaene, arriue not to make vp a perfect Harmony. What I haue fayl'd of this, You that haue approoued my other Workes, (when you haue read this) taxe me of. For the rest, Non ego Ventosae Ple∣bis, Suffragia venor.

DIV1.HEAD: The Deuil's Law Case. OR, When Women goe to Law, the Deuill is full of Businesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Prospero.
SP.L: YOu haue shewen a world of wealth;
I did not thinke there had bene a Merchant
Liu'd in Italy of halfe your substance.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Ile giue the King of Spaine
Ten thousand Duckets yearely, and discharge
My yearely Custome. The Hollanders scarse trade
More generally then I: my Factors wiues
Weare Shaperoones of Veluet, and my Scriueners
Meerely through my imployment, grow so rich,
They build their Palaces and Belvidears
With musicall Water-workes: Neuer in my life
Had I a losse at Sea. They call me on th'Exchange,
The fortunate Youngman and make great suite
To venture with me: Shall I tell you Sir,
Of a strange confidence in my way of Trading,
I reckon it as certaine as the gaine
In erecting a Lotterie.

SP.SPEAKER: Pros.
SP.L: I pray Sir, what doe you thinke
Of Signiour Baptisto's estate?

SP.SPEAKER: Rom
SP.L: A meere Begger▪
Hee's worth some fiftie thousand Duckets.

SP.SPEAKER: Pros.
SP.L: Is not that well?

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: How well? for a man to be melted to snow water,
With toyling in the world from three and twentie,
Till threescore for poore fiftie thousand Duckets.

SP.SPEAKER: Pros.
SP.L: To your estate 'tis little I confesse:
You haue the Spring-tide of Gold.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Faith, and for Siluer,
Should I not send it packing to th'East Indies,
We should haue a glut on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: Here's the great Lord Contarino.

SP.SPEAKER: Pro.
SP.L: Oh, I know his busines, he's a suitor to your sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Yes Sir, but to you,
As my most trusted friend, I vtter it,
I will breake the alliance.

SP.SPEAKER: Pros
SP.L: You are ill aduised then;
There liues not a compleater Gentleman
In Italy, nor of a more ancient house.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: What tell you me of Gentrie, 'tis nought else
But a superstitious relique of time past:
And sift it to the true worth, it is nothing
But ancient riches: and in him you know
They are pittifully in the wane; he makes his colour
Of visiting vs so often, to sell land,
And thinkes if he can gaine my sisters loue,
To recouer the treble value.

SP.SPEAKER: Pros.
SP.L: Sure he loues her intirely, and she deserues it.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Faith, though shee were
Crookt shoulderd, hauing such a portion,
Shee would haue noble Suitors; but truth is,
I would wish my noble Venturer take heed,
It may be whiles he hopes to catch a Gilt head,
He may draw vp a Gudgeon.

SP.SPEAKER: Pros
SP.L: Hee's come: Sir, I will leaue you.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: I sent you the Euidence of the peece of land
I motioned to you for the Sale.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Has your Counsell perus'd it?

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Not yet my Lord: Doe you intend to trauell?

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Oh then you loose
That which makes man most absolute.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P:
Yet I haue heard of diuers, that in passing of the
Alpes, haue but exchang'd their vertues at deare rate for other vices.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Oh my Lord, lye not idle;
The chiefest action for a man of great spirit,
Is neuer to be out of action: we should thinke
The soule was neuer put into the body,
Which has so many rare and curious pieces
Of Mathematicall motion, to stand still.
Vertue is euer sowing of her seedes:
In the Trenches for the Souldier; in the wakefull study
For the Scholler; in the sorrowes of the sea
For men of our Profession, of all which
Arise and spring vp Honor. Come, I know
You haue some noble great Designe in hand,
That you leuy so much money.

SP.SPEAKER: Cont.
SP.L: Sir, Ile tell you,
The greatest part of it I meane to imploy
In payment of my Debts, and the remainder
Is like to bring me into greater bonds, as I ayme it.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: How Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Cont.
SP.L: I intend it for the charge of my Wedding.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Are you to be married, my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Cont.
SP.L: Yes Sir; and I must now intreat your pardon,
That I haue concealed from you a businesse,
Wherein you had at first been call'd to Counsell,
But that I thought it a lesse fault in Friendship,
To ingage my selfe thus farre without your knowledge,
Then to doe it against your will: another reason
Was, that I would not publish to the world,
Nor haue it whispered scarce, what wealthy Voyage
I went about, till I had got the Myne
In mine owne possession.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: You are darke to me yet,

SP.SPEAKER: Com.
SP.L: Ile now remoue the cloud. Sir, your sister and I
Are vowed each others, and there onely wants
Her worthy mothers, and your faire consents
To stile it marriage: this is a way,
Not onely to make a friendship, but confirme it
For our posterities. How doe you looke vpon't?

SP.SPEAKER: Rom
SP.L: Beleeue me Sir, as on the principall Colume
To aduance our House: why you bring honour with you,
Which is the soule of Wealth. I shall be proud
To liue to see my little Nephewes ride
O'th vpper hand of their Vncles; and the Daughters
Be ranckt by Heraulds at Solemnities
Before the Mother: all this deriu'd
From your Nobilitie. Doe not blame me sir,
If I be taken with't exceedingly:
For this same honour with vs Citizens,
Is a thing we are mainely fond of, especially
When it comes without money, which is very seldome,
But as you doe perceiue my present temper,
Be sure I am yours, fierd with scorne and laughter,
At your ouer confident purpose, and no doubt,
My mother will be of your mind.

SP.SPEAKER: Cont.
SP.L: Tis my hope sir.
I doe obserue how this Romelio,
Has very worthy parts, were they not blasted
By insolent vaine glory: there rests now
The mothers approbation to the match,
Who is a woman of that State and bearing,
Tho shee be Citie-borne, both in her language,
Her Garments, and her Table, shee excels
Our Ladies of the Court: shee goes not gawdy,
Yet haue I seene her weare one Diamond,
Would haue bought twenty gay ones out of their clothes,
And some of them, without the greater grace,
Out of their honesties.
Shee comes, I will trie
How she stands affected to me, without relating
My Contract with her Daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.L: Sir, you are nobly welcome, and presume
You are in a place that's wholly dedicated
To your seruice.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: I am euer bound to you for many speciall fauours.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.L: Sir, your fame renders you most worthy of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Cont.
SP.L: It could neuer haue got a sweeter ayre to fly in,
Then your breath.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.L: You haue bin strange a long time, you are weary
Of our vnseasonable time of feeding:
Indeed th' Exchange Bell makes vs dine so late;
I thinke the Ladies of the Court from vs
Learne to lye so long a bed.

SP.SPEAKER: Cont.
SP.L: They haue a kind, of Exchange among them too,
Marry vnlesse, it be to heare of newes, I take it,
Theirs, is like the New Burse, thinly furnisht
With Tyers and new Fashions. I haue a suite to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.L: I would not haue you value it the lesse,
If I say, Tis granted already.

SP.SPEAKER: Cont.
SP.L: You are all Bounty, tis to bestow your
Picture on me.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.L: Oh sir, shaddowes, are coueted in Summer,
And with me, tis Fall o'th Leafe.

SP.SPEAKER: Cont.
SP.L: You enioy the best of Time;
This latter Spring of yours, shewes in my eye,
More fruitfull and more temperate withall,
Then that whose date is onely limitted
By the musicke of the Cuckow.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.L: Indeed Sir, I dare tell you,
My Looking-glasse is a true one, and as yet
It does not terrifie me. Must you haue my Picture?

SP.SPEAKER: Cont.
SP.L: So please you Lady, and I shall preserue it
As a most choyce Obiect.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.L: You will enioyne me to a strange punishment:
With what a compeld face a woman sits
While shee is drawing? I haue noted diuers,
Either to faine smiles, or sucke in the lippes,
To haue a little mouth; ruffle the cheekes,
To haue the dimple seene, and so disorder
The face with affectation, at next sitting
It has not been the same; I haue knowne others
Haue lost the intire fashion of their face,
In halfe an houres sitting.

SP.SPEAKER: Cont.
SP.L: How?

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.L: In hote weather,
The painting on their face has been so mellow,
They haue left the poore man harder worke by halfe,
To mend the Copie h wrought by▪ but indeed,
If euer I would haue mine drawen to'th life,
I would haue a Paynter steale it, at such a time,
I were deuoutly kneeling at my prayers,
There is then a heauenly beautie in't, the Soule
Moones in the Superficies.

SP.SPEAKER: Cont.
SP.L: Excellent Lady,
Now you teach Beautie a preseruatiue,
More then 'gainst fading Colours; and your iudgement
Is perfect in all things.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.L: Indeed Sir, I am a Widdow,
And want the addition to make it so:
For mans Experience has still been held
Womans best eyesight. I pray sir tell mee,
You are about to sell a piece of Land
To my sonne, I heare.

SP.SPEAKER: Cont.
SP.L: Tis truth.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.L: Now I could rather wish,
That Noble men would euer liue ith Countrey,
Rather then make their visit's vp to'th Citie
About such businesse: Oh Sir, Noble Houses
Haue no such goodly Prospects any way,
As into their owne Land: the decay of that,
Next to their begging Churchland, is a ruine
Worth all mens pitie. Sir, I haue forty thousand crownes
Sleepe in my Chest, shall waken when you please,
And slie to your commands, Will you stay supper?

SP.SPEAKER: Cont.
SP.L: I cannot, worthy Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.L: I would not haue you come hither sir, to sell,
But to settle your Estate. I hope you vnderstand
Wherefore I make this proffer: so I leaue you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cont.
SP.L: What a Treasury haue I pearch'd.
I hope you vnderstand wherefore I make this proffer.
Shee has got some intelligence, how I intend to marry
Her daughter, and ingenuously perceiued,
That by her Picture, which I begged of her,
I meant the faire Iolenta: here's a Letter,
Which giues expresse charge, not to visit her
Till midnight: faile not to come, for tis a businesse
That concernes both our honors.
Yours in danger to be lost, Iolenta.
Tis a strange Inunction; what should be the businesse?
She is not chang'd I hope. Ile thither straight:
For womens Resolutions in such deeds,
Like Bees, light oft on flowers, and oft on weeds.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom
SP.L: Oh sister come, the Taylor must to worke,
To make your wedding Clothes.

SP.SPEAKER: Jol.
SP.L: The Tombe-maker, to take measure of my cossin.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Tombe-maker? looke you,
The king of Spaine greets you.

SP.SPEAKER: Iol.
SP.L: What does this meane, do you serue Proces on me?

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Proces? come you would be wittie now.

SP.SPEAKER: Iol.
SP.L: Why, what's this, I pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Infinite grace to you▪ it is a Letter
From his Catholike Maiestie, for the commends
Of this Gentleman for your Husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Iol.
SP.L: In good season: I hope he will not haue my
Allegiance stretcht to the vndoing of my selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Vndoe your selfe? he does proclaime him here

SP.SPEAKER: Iol.
SP.L: Not for a Traytor, does he?

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: You are not mad;
For one of the Noblest Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Iol.
SP.L: Yet Kings many times
Know meerly but mens outsides, was this commendation
Voluntary, thinke you?

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Voluntary: what meane you by that?

SP.SPEAKER: Jol.
SP.L: Why I do not thinke but he beg'd it of the King,
And it may fortune to be out of's way:
Some better suite, that woo'd haue stood his Lordship
In farre more stead: Letters of Commendations,
Why tis reported that they are growen stale,
When places fall i'th Vniuersitie.
I pray you returne his Passe: for to a Widdow
That longs to be a Courtier, this Paper
May doe Knights seruice.

SP.SPEAKER: Erco.
SP.L: Mistake not excellent Mistres, these commends
Expresse, his Maiestie of Spaine has giuen me
Both addition of honour, as you may perceiue
By my habit, and a place heere to command
Ore thirtie Gallies; this your brother shewes,
As wishing that you would be partner
In my good Fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: I pray come hither, haue I any interest in you?

SP.SPEAKER: Iol
SP.L: You are my Brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: I would haue you then vse me with that respect,
You may still keepe me so, and to be swayed
In this maine businesse of life, which wants
Greatest consideration, your Marriage,
By my direction: Here's a Gentleman—

SP.SPEAKER: Iol.
SP.L: Sir, I haue often told you,
I am so little my owne to dispose that way,
That I can neuer be his.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Come, too much light
Makes you Moone-eyed, are you in loue with title?
I will haue a Herauld, whose continuall practise
Is all in pedigree, come a wooing to you,
Or an Antiquary in old Buskins.

SP.SPEAKER: Erco.
SP.L: Sir, you haue done me
The maynest wrong that ere was offred
To a Gentleman of my breeding.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Why sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Erco.
SP.L: You haue led me
With a vaine confidence, that I should marry
Your sister, haue proclaim'd it to my friends,
Employd the greatest Lawyers of our State
To settle her a ioynture, and the issue
Is, that I must become ridiculous
Both to my friends and enemies: I will leaue you,
Till I call to you for a strict account
Of your vnmanly dealing.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Stay my Lord.
Doe you long to haue my throat cut? Good my Lord,
Stay but a little, till I haue remooued
This Court-mist from her eyes, till I wake her
From this dull sleepe, wherein sheele dreame herselfe
To a deformed Begger: you would marry
The great Lord Contarino.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.L: Contarino
Were you talking of? he lost last night at Diee
Fiue thousand Duckets; and when that was gone,
Set at one throw a Lordship, that twice trebled
The former losse.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: And that flew after.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.L: And most carefully
Carried the Gentleman in his Carroch
To a Lawyers Chamber, there most Legally
To put him in possession: was this wisedome?

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: O yes, their credit in the way of gaming
Is the mayne thing they stand on, that must be paid,
Tho the Brewer bawle for's money; and this Lord
Does shee preferre i'th way of marriage,
Before our Choyce. Here noble Ercole,

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.L: Youle be aduis'd I hope: Know for your sakes
I married, that I might haue children;
And for your sakes, if youle be rul'd by me,
I will neuer marry agen. Here's a Gentleman
Is noble, rich, well featur'd, but 'boue all,
He loues you intirely; his intents are aymed
For an Expedition 'gainst the Turke,
Which makes the Contract cannot be delayed.

SP.SPEAKER: Io.
SP.L: Contract? you must do this without my knowledge;
Giue me some potion to make me mad,
And happily not knowing what I speake,
I may then consent too't.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Come, you are mad already,
And I shall neuer heare you speake good sense,
Till you name him for Husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Erco.
SP.L: Lady, I will doe a manly Office for you,
I will leaue you, to the freedome of your owne soule,
May it moue whither heauen and you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Iol.
SP.L: Now you expresse your selfe most nobly.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Stay sir, what doe you meane to doe?

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.L: Heare me, if thou dost marry Contarino,
All the misfortune that did euer dwell.
In a parents curse, light on thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Erc.
SP.L: Oh rise Lady, certainly heauen neuer intended
Kneeling to this fearefull purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: Iol.
SP.L: Your Imprecation has vndone me for euer.

SP.SPEAKER: Erc.
SP.L: Giue me your hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Iol.
SP.L: No sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Giu't rue then:
Oh what rare workmanship haue I seene this
To finish with your needle, what excellent musicke
Haue these strucke vpon the Violl!
Now Ile teach a piece of Art.

SP.SPEAKER: Iol.
SP.L: Rather a damnable cunning,
To haue me goe about to giu't away,
Without consent of my soule.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Kisse her my Lord, if crying had been regarded,
Maidenheads had nere been lost, at least some appearance
Of crying, as an Aprill showre i'th Sunshine.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.L: Shee is yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.P: Nay, continue your station, and deale you in dumbe shew; kisse this doggednesse out of her.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.L: To be contracted in teares, is but fashionable.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Yet suppose that they were heartie.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.L: Virgins must seeme vnwilling.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Oh what else; and you remember, we obserue the
Like in greater Ceremonies then these Contracts,
At the Conseration of Prelates, they vse euer
Twice to say nay, and take it.

SP.SPEAKER: Iolen.
SP.L: Oh Brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Ro.
SP.L: Keep your possession, you haue the dore bithring,
That's Liuery and Seasin in England; but my Lord,
Kisse that teare from her lip, youle find the Rose
The sweeter for the dewe.

SP.SPEAKER: Iolen.
SP.L: Bitter as gall.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: I, I, all you women,
Although you be of neuer so low stature,
Haue gall in you most abundant, it exceeds
Your braines by two ounces. I was saying somewhat;
Oh doe but obserue ith Citie, and youle finde
The thriftiest bargaines that were euer made,
What a deale of wrangling ere they could be brought
To an vpshot.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.L: Great persons doe not euer come together.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: With reuelling faces, nor is it necessary
They should; the strangenesse and vnwillingnesse
Weares the greater state, and giues occasion that
The people may buzz and talke of't, tho the Bells
Be tongue-tide at the Wedding.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.L: And truely I haue heard say,
To be a little strange to one another,
Will keepe your longing fresh.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom,
SP.L: I, and make you beget
More children when yare maried: some Doctors
Are of that opinion. You see my Lord, we are merry
At the Contract, your sport is to come hereafter.

SP.SPEAKER: Ercol.
SP.L: I will leaue you excellent Lady, and withall
Leaue a heart with you so entirely yours,
That I protest, had I the least of hope
To enioy you, tho I were to wayt the time
That Schollers doe in taking their degree
In the noble Arts, 'twere nothing, howsoere
He parts from you, that will depart from life,
To doe you any seruice, and so humbly
I take my leaue.

SP.SPEAKER: Jol.
SP.L: Sir, I will pray for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ro.
SP.L: Why thats well, 'twill make your prayer compleat,
To pray for your Husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Iol.
SP.L: Husband?

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.L: This is the happiest houre that I euer arriued at.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Husband, I husband: come you peeuish thing,
Smile me a thanke for the paynes I haue tane.

SP.SPEAKER: Iol.
SP.L: I hate my selfe for being thus enforst,
You may soone iudge then what I thinke of you
Which are the cause of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: You Lady of the Laundry, come hither.

SP.SPEAKER: Wayt.
SP.L: Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Looke as you loue your life, you haue an eye
Vpon your Mistresse; I doe henceforth barre her
All Visitants: I do heare there are Bawds abroad,
That bring Cut-works, & Man-toons, & conuey Letters
To such young Gentlewomen, and there are others
That deale in Corne-cutting, and Fortune-telling,
Let none of these come at her on your life,
Nor Dewes ace the wafer woman, that prigs abroad
With Muskmeloons, and Malakatoones;
Nor the Scotchwoman with the Citterne, do you marke,
Nor a Dancer by any meanes, tho he ride on's foot-cloth,
Nor a Hackney Coachman, if he can speake French.

SP.SPEAKER: Wayt.
SP.L: Why sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: By no meanes: no more words;
Nor the woman with Maribone puddings. I haue heard
Strange iugling tricks haue been conueyd to a woman
In a pudding: you are apprehensiue?

SP.SPEAKER: Wayt.
SP.L: Oh good sir, I haue traueld.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: When you had a Bastard, you traueld indeed:
But my precious Chaperoones,
I trust thee the better for that; for I haue heard,
There is no warier Keeper of a Parke,
To preuent Stalkers, or your Night-walkers,
Then such a man, as in his youth has been
A most notorious Deare-stealer.

SP.SPEAKER: Wayt.
SP.L: Very well sir,
You may vse me at your pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: By no meanes Winifrid, that were the way
To make thee trauell agen: Come be not angry,
I doe but iest, thou knowest, wit and a woman,
Are two very fraile things, and so I leaue you.

SP.SPEAKER: Wayt.
SP.L: I could weepe with you, but tis no matter,
I can doe that at any time, I haue now
A greater mind to rayle a little: Plague of these
Vnsanctified Matches; they make vs lothe
The most naturall desire our grandame Eue euer left vs.
Force one to marry against their will; why 'tis
A more vngodly worke, then inclosing the Commons.

SP.SPEAKER: Iolen.
SP.L: Prethee peace;
This is indeed an argument so common,
I cannot thinke of matter new ynough,
To expresse it bad enough,

SP.SPEAKER: Wayt.
SP.L: Heere's one I hope will put you out of't.

SP.SPEAKER: Cont.
SP.L: How now sweet Mistris?
You haue made sorrow looke louely of late,
You haue wept.

SP.SPEAKER: Wait.
SP.P: She has done nothing else these three dayes; had you stood behinde the Arras, to haue heard her shed so much salt water as I haue done, you would haue thought she had been turn'd Fountaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: I would faine know the cause can be worthy this
Thy sorrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Iol.
SP.L: Reach me the Caskanet, I am studying Sir,
To take an Inuentory of all that's mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: What to doe with it Lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Iol.
SP.L: To make you a Deed of gift.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: That's done already; you are all mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Wai.
SP.L: Yes, but the Deuil would faine put in for's share,
In likenesse of a Separation.

SP.SPEAKER: Iol.
SP.L: Oh sir, I am bewitcht.

SP.SPEAKER: Con
SP.L: Ha?

SP.SPEAKER: Iol.
SP.L: Most certaine, I am forespoken,
To be married to another: can you euer thinke
That I shall euer thriue in't? Am I not then bewitcht?
All comfort I can teach my selfe is this,
There is a time left for me to dye nobly,
When I cannot liue so?

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Giue me in a word, to whom, or by whose meanes
Are you thus torne from me?

SP.SPEAKER: Iol.
SP.L: By Lord Ercole, my Mother, and by Brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Cont.
SP.L: Ile make his brauery fitter for a graue,
Then for a wedding.

SP.SPEAKER: Jolen.
SP.L: So you will beget
A farre more dangerous and strange disease
Out of the cure; you must loue him agen
For my sake: for the noble Ercole
Had such a true compassion of my sorrow.
Harke in your eare, He shew you his right worthy
Demeanour to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Wayt.
SP.L: Oh you pretty ones,
I haue seene this Lord many a time and oft
Set her in's lap, and talke to her of Loue
So feelingly, I doe protest it has made me
Run out of my selfe to thinke on't; oh sweet breath'd
Monkey, how they grow together? well, tis my opinion,
He was no womans friend that did inuent
A punishment for kissing.

SP.SPEAKER: Cont.
SP.L: If he beare himselfe so nobly,
The manliest office I can doe for him,
Is to affoord him my pitie, since h e's like
To faile of so deare a purchase: for your mother,
Your goodnesse quits her ill; for your brother,
He that vowes friendship to a man, and prooues
A traytor deserues rather to be hang d,
Then he that counterfets money; yet for your sake
I must signe his pardon too. Why doe you tremble?
Be safe, you are now free from him.

SP.SPEAKER: Iolen.
SP.L: Oh but sir,
The intermission from a it of an ague
Is grieuous: for indeed it doth prepare vs,
To entertaine torment next morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Cont.
SP.L: Why hee's gone to sea.

SP.SPEAKER: Iol.
SP.L: But he may returne too soone.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: To auoyd which, we will instantly be maried.

SP.SPEAKER: Wa.
SP.L: To auoid which, get you instantly to bed together,
Doe, and I thinke no Ciuill Lawyer for his fee
Can giue you better Councell.

SP.SPEAKER: Iol.
SP.L: Fye vpon thee, prethee leaue vs.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Be of comfort sweet Mistris.

SP.SPEAKER: Jol.
SP.L: On one condition we may haue no quarrell about

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Vpon my life none. (this.

SP.SPEAKER: Iol.
SP.L: None vpon your honour?

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: With whom? with Ercole?
You haue deliuered him guiltlesse.
With your Brother? Hee's part of your selfe.
With your complementall Mother?
I vse not sight with women
To morrow weele be married:
Let those that would oppose this vnion,
grow nere so subtill, and intangle themselues
In their owne worke like Spiders, while we two
Haste to our noble wishes, and presume,
The hindrance of it will breed more delight,
As black copartaments shewes gold more bright.

SP.SPEAKER: Crisp
SP.L: Am I well habited?

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.P: Exceeding well; any man would take you for a Merchant: but pray sir resolue me, what should bee the reason, that you being one of the most eminent Ciuill Lawyers in Spaine, and but newly arriued from the East Indies, should take this habit of a Marchant vpon you?

SP.SPEAKER: Crisp.
SP.L: Why my sonne liues here in Naples & in's riot
Doth farre exceed the exhibition I allowed him.

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.L: So then, & in this disguise you meane to trace him.

SP.SPEAKER: Cri.
SP.L: Partly for that, but there is other businesse
Of greater consequence.

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.P: Faith for his expence, tis nothing to your estate, What to Don Crispiano, the famous Corrigidor of Ciuill, who by his meere practise of the Law, in lesse time then halfe a Iubile, hath gotten thirtie thousand Duckets a yeare.

SP.SPEAKER: Crisp.
SP.L: Well, I will giue him line,
Let him run on in's course of spending.

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.L: Freely?

SP.SPEAKER: Crisp.
SP.L: Freely:
For I protest, if that I could conceaue
My sonne would take more pleasure or content,
By any course of ryot, in the expence,
Then I tooke ioy, nay soules felicitie
In the getting of it, should all the wealth I haue
Waste to as small an atomy as Flies
I'th 'unne, I doe protest on that condition,
It should not mooue mee.

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.P: How's this? Cannot hee take more peasure in spending it ryotously, then you haue done by scraping it together: O ten thousand times more, and I make no question, fiue hundred yong gallants wil be of my opiniō.
SP.L: Why all the time of your Collectionship,
Has bene a perpetuall Callender, begin first
With your melancholly studie of the Law
Before you come to singer the Ruddocks, after that
The tyring importunitie of Clyents,
To rise so early, and sit vp so late,
You made your selfe halfe ready in a dreame,
And neuer prayed but in your sleepe: Can I thinke,
That you haue halfe your lungs left with crying out
For Iudgements, and dayes of Tryall. Remember sir,
How often haue I borne you on my shoulder,
Among a shale or swarme of reeking Night-caps,
When that your Worship has bepist yourselfe,
Either with vehemency of Argument,
Or being out from the matter. I am merry.

SP.SPEAKER: Crisp.
SP.L: Be so.

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.L: You could eat like a Gentleman, at leasure;
But swallow it like lap-dragons, as if you had liued
With chewing the Cud after.

SP.SPEAKER: Crisp.
SP.L: No pleasure in the world was comparable too't.

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.L: Possible?

SP.SPEAKER: Crisp.
SP.L: He shall neuer taste the like, vnlesse he study law.

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.L: What, not in wenching sir?
Tis a Court game, beleeue it,
As familiar as Gleeke, or any other.

SP.SPEAKER: Crisp
SP.L: Wenching? O fie, the Disease followes it:
Beside, can the fingring Taffaties, or Lawnes,
Or a painted hand, or a Brest be like the pleasure
In taking Clyents fees, and piling them
In seuerall goodly rowes before my Deske?
And according to the bignesse of each heape,
Which I tooke by a leare: for Lawyers do not tell them,
I vayl'd my cap, and withall gaue great hope
The Cause should goe on their sides.

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.L: What thinke you then
Of a good crie of Hounds? It has bene knowen
Dogs haue hunted Lordships to a fault.

SP.SPEAKER: Crisp.
SP.L: Cry of Curres?
The noyse of Clyents at my Chamber doore,
Was sweeter Musicke farre, in my conceit,
Then all the Hanting in Europe.

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.L: Pray stay sir,
Say he should spend it in good House-keeping.

SP.SPEAKER: Crisp.
SP.L: I marry sir, to haue him keepe a good house,
And not sell't away, Ide find no fault with that:
But his Kitchin, Ide haue no bigger then a Saw-pit;
For the smalnesse of a Kitchin without question,
Makes many Noblemen in France and Spaine,
Build the rest of the house the bigger.

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.L: Yes, Mock-beggers.

SP.SPEAKER: Crisp.
SP.L: Some seuenscore Chimneyes,
But halfe of them haue no Tonnels.

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.L: A pox vpon them Cuckshawes that beget
Such monsters without fundaments.

SP.SPEAKER: Crisp.
SP.L: Come, come, leaue citing other vanities;
For neither Wine, nor Lust, nor riotous feasts,
Rich cloathes, nor all the pleasure that the Deuill
Has euer practis'd with, to raise a man
To a Deuils likenesse, ere brought man that pleasure
I tooke in getting my wealth: so I conclude.
If he can out-vie me, let it flie to'th Deuill.
Yon's my sonne, what company keepes he?

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.L: The Gentleman he talks with,
Is Romelio the Merchant.

SP.SPEAKER: Crisp.
SP.L: I neuer saw him till now,
A has a braue sprightly looke, I knew his father,
And soiourn'd in his house two yeares together,
Before this young mans birth; I haue newes to tell him
Of certaine losses happened him at Sea,
That will not please him.

SP.SPEAKER: San
SP.L: What that dapper fellow
In the long stocking? I doe thinke 'twas he
Came to your lodging this morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Crisp.
SP.L: Tis the same,
There he stands, but a little piece of flesh,
But he is the very myracle of a Lawyer,
One that perswades men to peace, & compounds quarrels
Among his neighbours, without going to law.

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.L: And is he a Lawyer?

SP.SPEAKER: Crisp.
SP.L: Yes, and will giue counsell
In honest causes gratis, neuer in his life
Tooke fee, but he came and spake for't, is a man
Of extreame practise, and yet all his longing,
Is to become a Iudge.

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.P: Indeed that's a rare longing with men of his pro∣fession. I think heel proue the miracle of a lawier indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.P: Heere's the man brought word your father dyed i'th Indies.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: He died in perfect memory I hope,
And made me his heyre.

SP.SPEAKER: Cri.
SP.L: Yes sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: He's gone the right way then without question:
Friend, in time of mourning, we must not vse any action,
That is but accessary to the making men merry,
I doe therefore giue you nothing for your good tidings.

SP.SPEAKER: Cris.
SP.L: Nor doe I looke for it sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.P: Honest fellow, giue me thy hand, I doe not thinke but thou hast carried New yeares gifts to'th Court in thy dayes, and learndst there to be so free of thy paynes taking.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.P: Here's an old Gentleman sayes he was chamber∣fellow to your father, when they studied the Law toge∣ther at Barcellona.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul
SP.L: Doe you know him?

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Not I, he's newly come to Naples.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: And what's his businesse?

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: A sayes he's come to read you good counsell.

SP.SPEAKER: Crisp.
SP.L: To him, rate him soundly.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: And what's your counsell?

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.L: Why, I would haue you leaue your whoring.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: He comes hotly vpon me at first: whoring?

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.L: O yong quat, incontinence is plagued
In all the creatures of the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: When did you euer heare, that a Cockesparrow
Had the French poxe?

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.P: When did you euer know any of them fat, but in the nest? aske all your Cantaride-mongers that question; remember your selfe sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.P: A very fine Naturallist, a Phisician, I ae you by your round slop; for tis iust of the bignes, and no more, of the case for a Vrinall: tis concluded, you are a Phisician. What doe you meane sir, youl take cold.

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.P: Tis concluded, ou are a foole, a precious one, you are a meere sticke of Sugar Candy, a man may looke quite thorow you

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.L: You are a very bold gamester.

SP.SPEAKER: Ar.
SP.L: I can play at chesse, & know how to handle a rook.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: Pray preserue your veluet from the dust.

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.L: Keepe your hat vpon the blocke sir,
'Twill continue fashion the longer.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: I was neuer so abused with the hat in the hand
In my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.L: I will put on, why looke you,
Those lands that were the Clyents, are now become
The Lawyers; and those tenements that were
The Countrey Gentlemans, are now growen
To be his Taylors.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: Taylors?

SP.SPEAKER: Ario.
SP.L: Yes, Taylors in France, they grow to great
Abominable purchase, and become great officers.
How many Duckets thinke you he has spent
Within a tweluemonth, besides his fathers allowance?

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: Besides my fathers allowance?
Why Gentleman, doe you thinke an Auditor begat me?
Would you haue me make euen at yeares end?

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.P: A hundred duckets a month in breaking Venice glasses.

SP.SPEAKER: Ario.
SP.L: He learnt that of an English drunkard,
And a Knight too, as I take it.
This comes of your numerous Wardrobe.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: I, and wearing Cut-worke, a pound a Purle.

SP.SPEAKER: Ario
SP.L: Your daintie embroydered stockings,
With ouerblowne Roses, to hide your gowtie anckles.

SP.SPEAKER: Ro.
SP.P: And wearing more taffaty for a garter, then would serue the Gally dung-boat for streamers. (strissimi.

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.L: Your switching vp at the horse-race, with the Illu-

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.P: And studying a pussing Arithmatick at the cock∣pit.

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.L: Shaking your elbow at the Taule-boord.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: And resorting to your whore in hir'd veluet,
With a spangled copper fringe at her netherlands.

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.L: Whereas if you had staid at Padua, and fed vpon
Cow trotters, and fresh beefe to Supper.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: How I am bayted?

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.P: Nay, be not you so forward with him neither, for tis thought, youle proue a maine part of his vndoing.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: I thinke this fellow is a witch

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Who I sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.P: You haue certaine rich citie Chuffes, that when they haue no acres of their owne, they will goe and plow vp fooles, and turne them into excellent meadow; besides some Inclosures for the first Cherries in the Spring,
And Apricocks to pleasure a friend at Court with.

You haue Potecaries deal in selling commodities to yong Gallants, will put foure or fiue coxcombs into a sieue, and so drumme with them vpon their Counter; theyle searse
them through like Ginny Pepper, they cannot endure to finde a man like a payre of Tarriers, they would vndoe him in a trice.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: May be there are such.

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.L: O terrible exactors, fellowes with six hands,
And three heads.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: I those are Hell hounds.

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.P: Take heed of them, theyle rent thee like Tenter∣hookes. Hearke in your eare, there is intelligence vpon you; the report goes, there has been gold conueyd beyond the Sea in hollow Aneres. Farewell, you shall know mee better, I will doe thee more good, then thou art aware of.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: Hee's a mad fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.L: He would haue made an excellent Barber,
He does so curry it with his tongue.

SP.SPEAKER: Crisp.
SP.L: Sir, I was directed to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: From whence?

SP.SPEAKER: Crisp.
SP.L: From the East Indies.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: You are very welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Cri.
SP.L: Please you walke apart,
I shall acquaint you with particulars
Touching your Trading i'th East Indies.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Willingly, pray walke sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Erc.
SP.P: Oh my right worthy friends, you haue staid me long, one health, and then aboord; for all the Gallies are come about.

SP.SPEAKER: Cont.
SP.L: Signior Ercol,
The wind has stood my friend sir, to preuent
Your putting to Sea.

SP.SPEAKER: Erc.
SP.L: Pray why sit?

SP.SPEAKER: Cont.
SP.L: Onely loue sir,
That I might take my leaue sir, and withall
Intreat from you a priuate recommends
To a friend in Malta, 'twould be deliuered
To your bosome, for I had no time to write.

SP.SPEAKER: Erc.
SP.L: Pray leaue vs Gentlemen.
Wilt please you sit?

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Sir, my loue to you has proclaim'd you one,
Whose word was still led by a noble thought,
And that thought followed by as faire a died:
Deceiue not that opinion, we were Students
At Padua together, and haue long
To'th worlds ye shewen like friends,
Was it hartie on your part to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Erc.
SP.L: Vnfained.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: You are false
To the good thought I held of you, and now
Ioyne the worst part of man to you, your malice,
To vphold that falsehood, sacred innocence
Is fled your bosome. Signior, I must tell you,
To draw the picture of vnkindnesse truely,
Is to expresse two that haue dearly loued,
And falne at variance; tis a wonder to me,
Knowing my interest in the fayre Iolenta,
That you should loue her.

SP.SPEAKER: Erc.
SP.L: Compare her beauty, and my youth together,
And you will find the faire effects of loue
No myracle at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Con
SP.L: Yes, it will proue prodigious to you.
I must stay your Voyage.

SP.SPEAKER: Erc.
SP.L: Your Warrant must be mightie.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: 'Tas a Seale from heauen
To doe it, since you would rauish from me
What's there entitled mine: and yet I vow,
By the essentiall front of spotlesse Vertue,
I haue compassion of both our youths:
To approue which, I haue not tane the way,
Like an Italian, to cut your throat
By practise, that had giuen you now for dead,
And neuer frownd vpon you.

SP.SPEAKER: Erc.
SP.L: You deale faire sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Quit me of one doubt, pray sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Erc.
SP.L: Moue it.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Tis this,
Whether her Brother were a maine Instrument
In her designe for Marriage.

SP.SPEAKER: Erc.
SP.L: If I tell truth, you will not credit me.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Why?

SP.SPEAKER: Erc.
SP.L: I will tell you truth,
Yet shew some reason you haue not to beleeue me:
Her Brother had no hand in't, ist not hard
For you to credit this: for you may thinke,
I count it basenesse to ingage another
Into my quarrell; and for that take leaue
To dissemble the truth. Sir, if you will fight
With any but my selfe, fight with her Mother,
Shee was the motiue.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: I haue no enemy in the world then, but your selfe;
You must fight with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Erc.
SP.L: I will sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: And instantly.

SP.SPEAKER: Erc.
SP.L: I will haste before you, poynt whither.

SP.SPEAKER: Con
SP.L: Why you speake nobly, and for this faire dealing,
Were the rich Iewell which we vary for,
A thing to be diuided, by my life,
I would be well content to giue you halfe:
But since tis vaine to thinke we can be friends,
Tis needfull one of vs be tane away,
From being the others enemy.

SP.SPEAKER: Erc.
SP.L: Yet me thinks, this looks not like a quarrell.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Not a quarrell?

SP.SPEAKER: Erc.
SP.L: You haue not apparelled your sury well,
It goes too plaine like a Scholler.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: It is an ornament makes it more terrible,
And you shall finde it
A weightie iniury, and attended on
By discreet valour; because I doe not strike you,
Or giue you the lye, such foule preparatiues
Would show like the stale iniury of Wine.
I reserue my rage to sit on my swords poynt,
Which a great quantitie of your best blood
Cannot satisfie.

SP.SPEAKER: Erc.
SP.L: You promise well to your selfe.
Shall's haue no Seconds?

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: None, for feare of preuention.

SP.SPEAKER: Erc.
SP.L: The length of our weapons.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Weele sit them by the way:
So whether our time calls vs to liue or dye,
Let vs doe both like noble Gentlemen,
And true Italians.

SP.SPEAKER: Erc.
SP.L: For that let me embrace you:

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Me thinks, being an Italian, I trust you
To come somewhat too neere me:
But your Ielousie gaue that embrace to trie
If I were armed, did it not.

SP.SPEAKER: Erc.
SP.L: No beleeue me,
I take your heart to be sufficient proofe,
Without a priuie coat; and for my part,
A Taffaty is all the shirt of Mayle
I am armed with.

SP.SPEAKER: Cont.
SP.L: You deale equally.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: Where are these Gallants, the braue Ercole,
And noble Contarino?

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: They are newly gone sir,
And bade me tell you, that they will returne
Within this halfe houre.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: Met you the Lord Ercole?

SP.SPEAKER: Rom
SP.L: No, but I met the deuill in villanous tydings.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: Why, what's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Oh I am powr'd out like water, the greatest
Riuers i'th world are lost in the Sea,
And so am I: pray leaue me.
Where's Lord Ercole?

SP.SPEAKER: Iu.
SP.L: You were scarse gone hence, but in came Contarino.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Contarino?

SP.SPEAKER: Iu.
SP.L: And intreated some priuate conference with Ercole,
And on the sudden they haue giu'ns the slip.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: One mischiefe neuer comes alone:
They are gone to fight.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: To fight?

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: And you be Gentlemen,
Doe not talke, but make haste after them.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: Let's take seuerall wayes then,
And if't be possible for womens sakes,
For they are proper men, vse our endeauours,
That the pricke doe not spoyle them.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Youle not forgoe your interest in my Mistris?

SP.SPEAKER: Erc.
SP.L: My sword shall answer that; come, are you ready?

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Before you fight sir, thinke vpon your cause,
It is a wondrous foule one, and I wish,
That all your exercise these foure dayes past,
Had been imploy'd in a most feruent prayer,
And the foule sinne for which you are to fight
Chiefly remembred in't.

SP.SPEAKER: Erc.
SP.L: Ide as soone take
Your counsell in Diuinitie at this present,
As I would take a kind direction from you
For the managing my weapon; and indeed,
Both would shew much alike.
Come are you ready?

SP.SPEAKER: Con
SP.L: Bethinke your selfe,
How faire the obiect is that we contend for.

SP.SPEAKER: Erc.
SP.L: Oh, I cannot forget it.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: You are hurt.

SP.SPEAKER: Erc.
SP.L: Did you come hither only to tell me so,
Or to doe it? I meane well, but 'twill not thriue.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Your cause, your cause sir:
Will you yet be a man of Conscience, and make
Restitution for your rage vpon your death-bed?

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: Neuer, till the graue gather one of vs.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: That was faire, and home I thinke.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: You prate as if you were in a Fence-schoole.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Spare your youth, haue compassion on your selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: When I am all in pieces, I am now vnsit
For any Ladies bed; take the rest with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: I am lost in too much daring: yeeld your sword.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: To the pangs of death I shall, but not to thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: You are now at my repayring, or confusion:
Begge your life.

SP.SPEAKER: Erc
SP.L: Oh most foolishly demaunded,
To bid me beg that which thou canst not giue.
SP.STAGE: Enter Romelio, Prosp. Bapt. Ario Iulio.

SP.SPEAKER: Pro.
SP.L: See both of them are lost; we come too late.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Take vp the body, and conuey it
To Saint Sebastians Monastery.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: I will not part with his sword, I haue won't.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: You shall not:
Take him vp gently: so, and bow his body,
For feare of bleeding inward.
Well, these are perfect louers.

SP.SPEAKER: Pros.
SP.L: Why, I pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: It has been euer my opinion,
That there are none loue perfectly indeed,
But those that hang or drowne themselues for loue:
Now these haue chose a death next to Beheading,
They haue cut one anothers throats,
Braue valiant Lads.

SP.SPEAKER: Pro.
SP.L: Come, you doe ill, to set the name of valour
Vpon a violent and mad despaire.
Hence may all learne, that count such actions well,
The roots of fury shoot themselues to hell.

SP.SPEAKER: Ario.
SP.L: Your losses I confesse, are infinite,
Yet sir, you must haue patience.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Sir, my losses I know, but you I doe not.

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.L: Tis most true, I am but a stranger to you, but am
Wisht by some of your best friends, to visit you,
And out of my experience in the world,
To instruct you patience.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Of what profession are you?

SP.SPEAKER: Ario.
SP.L: Sir, I am a Lawyer.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Of all men liuing,
You Lawyers I account the onely men
To confirme patience in vs, your delayes
Would make three parts of this little Christian world
Run out of their wits else.
Now I remember, you read Lectures to Iulio,
Are you such a Leech for patience?

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.L: Yes sir, I haue had some crosses.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: You are married then I am certaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.L: That I am sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: And haue you studied patience?

SP.SPEAKER: Ario.
SP.L: You shall find I haue.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Did you euer see your wife make you Cuckold?

SP.SPEAKER: Ario.
SP.L: Make me Cuckold?

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: I aske it seriously, and you haue not seene that,
Your patience has not tane the right degree
Of wearing Scarlet; I should rather take you
For a Batchelor in the Art, then for a Doctor.

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.L: You are merry. (angry.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: No sir, with leaue of your patience, I am horrible

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.L: What should mooue you?
Put forth that harsh Interrogatory, if these eyes
Euer saw my wife doe the thing you wot of.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Why Ile tell you,
Most radically to try your patience,
And the meere question shewes you but a Dunse in't.
It has made you angry; there's another Lawyers beard
In your forehead, you doe brissle.

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.L: You are very conceited:
But come, this is not the right way to cure you.
I must talke to you like a Diuine.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom
SP.L: I haue heard some talk of it very much, and many
times to their Auditors impatience; but I pray,
What practise doe they make of't in their liues?
They are too full of choller with liuing honest,
And some of them not onely impatient
Of their owne sleightest iniuries, but starke mad,
At one anothers preferment: now to you sir,
I haue lost three goodly Carracks.

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.L: So I heare.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: The very Spice in them,
Had they been shipwrackt heere vpon our coast,
Would haue made all our Sea a Drench.

SP.SPEAKER: Ario.
SP.L: All the sicke horses in Italy
Would haue been glad of your losse them.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: You are conceited too,

SP.SPEAKER: Ario.
SP.L: Come, come, come,
You gaue those ships most strange, most dreadfull,
And vnfortunate names, I neuer lookt they'd prosper.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Is there any ill Omen in giuing names to ships?

SP.SPEAKER: Ario.
SP.L: Did you not call one, The Stormes Defiance;
Another, The Scourge of the Sea; and the third, The great Leuiathan?

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Very right sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.L: Very deuillish names
All three of them: and surely I thinke,
They were curst in their very cradles, I doe meane,
When they were vpon their Stockes.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Come, you are superstitious,
Ile giue you my opinion, and tis serious:
I am perswaded there came not Cuckolds enow
To the first Launching of them,
And 'twas that made them thriue the worse for't.
Oh your Cuckolds hansell is praid for i'th Citie.

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.L: I will heare no more,
Giue me thy hand, my intent of comming hither,
Was to perswade you to patience; as I liue,
If euer I doe visit you agen,
It shall be to intreat you to be angry, sure I will,
Ile be as good as my word, beleeue it.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: So sir: how now?
Are the Scritch-owles abroad already?

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.L: What a dismall noyse yon bell makes,
Sure some great person's dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: No such matter,
It is the common Bell-man goes about,
To publish the sale of goods.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.L: Why doe they ring before my gate thus?
Let them into'th Court, I cannot vnderstand
What they say.
SP.STAGE: Enter two Belmen and a Capouchin.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: For pities sake, you that haue teares to shed,
Sigh a soft Requiem, and let fall a Bead,
For two vnfortunate Nobles, whose sad fate
Leaues them both dead, and excommunicate:
No Churchmans prayer to comfort their last groanes,
No sacred seed of earth to hide their bones;
But as their fury wrought them out of breath,
The Canon speakes them guiltie of their owne death.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.L: What Noble men I pray sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: The Lord Ercole, and the noble Contarino,
Both of them slaine in single combat.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: O, I am lost for euer.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Denide Christian buriall, I pray what does that,
Or the dead lazy march in the Funerall,
Or the flattery in the Epitaphs, which shewes
More sluttish farre then all the Spiders webs
Shall euer grow vpon it: what doe these
Adde to our well being after death?

SP.SPEAKER: Capu.
SP.L: Not a scruple.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Very well then,
I haue a certaine Meditation,
If I can thinke of somewhat to this purpose,
Ile say it to you, while my mother there
Numbers her Beades.
You that dwell neere these graues and vaults,
Which oft doe hide Physicions faults,
Note what a small Roome does suffice,
To expresse mens good, their vanities,
Would fill more volume in small hand,
Then all the Euidence of Church-land.
Funerals hide men in ciuill wearing,
And are to the Drapers a good hearing,
Make the Heraulds laugh in their blacke Payment,
And all die Worthies die worth payment.
To the Altar Offerings, tho their fame,
And all the charitie of their name,
'Tweene heauen and this yeeld no more light,
Then rotten trees, which shine i'th night.
Oh looke the last Act be the best i'th Play,
And then rest gentle bones, yet pray,
That when by the precise you are vewed,
A Supersede as be not sued,
To remooub you to a place more ayrie,
That in your stead they may keepe chary
Stockfish, or Seacole, for the abuses
Of sacriledge haue turn'd graues to vilder vses.
How then can any Monument say,
Here rest these bones, till the last day,
When time swift both of foo and feather,
May beare them the Sexton ens not whither.
What care I then, tho my last sleepe,
Be in the Desart, or in the deepe,
No Lampe, nor Taper, day and night,
To giue my Charnell chargeable light:
I haue there like quantitie of ground,
And at the last day I shall be found.
Now I pray leaue me.

SP.SPEAKER: Capu.
SP.L: I am sorry for your losses.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Vm sir the more spatious that the Tennis court is,
The more large is the Hazard.
I dare the spitefull Fortune doe her worst,
I can now feare nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Capu.
SP.L: Oh sir, yet consider,
He that is without feare, is without hope,
And sins from presumption; better thoughts attend you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ro.
SP.L: Poore Iolenta, should she heare of this?
Shee would not after the report keepe fresh,
So long as flowers in graues.
How now Prospero.

SP.SPEAKER: Pro.
SP.L: Contarino has sent you here his Will,
Wherein a has made your sister his sole heire.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom
SP.L: Is he not dead?

SP.SPEAKER: Pro.
SP.L: Hee's yet liuing.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Liuing? the worse lucke.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: The worse: I doe protest it is the best,
That euer came to disturbe my prayers.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: How?

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.L: Yet I would haue him liue
To satisfie publique Iustice for the death
Of Ercole: oh goe visit him for heauens sake.
I haue within my Closet a choyce Relicke,
Preseruatiue 'gainst swounding, and some earth,
Brought from the Holy Land, right soueraigne
To staunch bloud: has he skilfull Surgeons, thinke you?

SP.SPEAKER: Pro.
SP.L: The best in Naples?

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: How oft has he been drest?

SP.SPEAKER: Pro.
SP.L: But once.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: I haue some skill this way:
The second or third dressing will shew clearely,
Whether there be hope of life: I pray be neere him,
If there be any soule can bring me word,
That there is hope of life.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Doe you prise his life so?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: That he may liue;
I meane to come to his try all, to satisfie the Law.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Oh, ist nothing else?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo
SP.L: I shall be the happiest woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Here is cruelty appareled in kindnesse.
I am ful of thoughts, strāge ones, but they'r no good ones.
I must visit Contarino, vpon that
Depends an Engine shall weigh vp my losses,
Were they sunke as low as hell; yet let me thinke,
How I am impayred in a houre, and the cause of't,
Lost in securitie: oh how this wicked world bewitches,
Especially made insolent with riches:
So Sayles with fore-winds stretcht, doe soonest breake,
And Piramides ath top, are still most weake.
SP.STAGE: Enter Capuchin, Ercole led betweene two.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.P: Looke vp sir, you are preserued beyond naturall reason, you were brought dead out a'th field, the Surgeons ready to haue embalmed you.

SP.SPEAKER: Erc.
SP.L: I do looke on my action with a thought of terror,
To doe ill and dwell in't, is vnmanly.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: You are diuinely informed sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Erc.
SP.L: I fought for one, in whom I haue no more right,
Then false executors haue in Orphans goods,
They cozen them of; yet tho my cause were naught,
I rather chose the hazard of my soule,
Then foregoe the complement of a chollerick man.
I pray continue the report of my death, and giue out,
Cause the Church denyed me Christian buriall,
The Vice admirall of my Gallies tooke my body,
With purpose to commit it to the earth,
Either in Cicil, or Malta.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: What ayme you at by this rumour of your death?

SP.SPEAKER: Erc.
SP.L: There is hope of life
In Contarino; and he has my prayers,
That he may liue to enioy what is his owne,
The faire Iolenta; where, should it be thought
That I were breathing, happily her friends
Would oppose it still.

SP.SPEAKER: Capu.
SP.L: But if you be supposed dead,
The Law will strictly prosecute his life
For your murder.

SP.SPEAKER: Erc.
SP.L: That's preuented thus,
There does belong a noble Priuiledge
To all his Family, euer since his father,
Bore from the worthy Emperour Charles the fift,
An answere to the French Kings challenge, at such time
The two noble Princes were ingag'd to fight.
Vpon a frontier arme o'th sea in a flat-bottom'd Boat,
That if any of his Family should chance
To kill a man i'th Field, in a noble cause,
He should haue his Pardon; now sir, for his cause,
The world may iudge if it were not honest.
Pray helpe me in speech, tis very painfull to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Capu
SP.L: Sir I shall.

SP.SPEAKER: Erc.
SP.L: The guilt of this lyes in Romelio,
And as I heare, to second this good Contract,
He has got a Nun with child.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: These are crimes that either must make worke
For speedy repentance, or for the Deuill.

SP.SPEAKER: Erc.
SP.L: I haue much compassion on him,
For sinne and shame are euer tyde together,
With Gordion knots, of such a strong threed spun,
They cannot without violence be vndone.

SP.SPEAKER: Ariost.
SP.L: Well sir, now I must claime your promise,
To reueale to me the cause why you liue thus clouded.

SP.SPEAKER: Crisp.
SP.L: Sir, the King of Spaine
Suspects, that your Romelio here, the Merchant
Has discouer'd some Gold-myne to his owne vse,
In the West Indies, and for that employes me,
To discouer in what part of Christendome
He vents this I reasure: Besides, he is informed
What mad tricks has bin plaid of late by Ladies.

SP.SPEAKER: Ari
SP.L: Most true, and I am glad the King has heard on't:
Why they vse their Lords, as if they were their Wards;
And as your Dutchwomen in the Low-Countries,
Take all and pay all, and doe keepe their Husbands
So silly all their liues of their owne estates,
That when they are sicke, and come to make their Will,
They know not precisely what to giue away
From their wiues, because they know not what they are
So heare should I repeat what factions, (worth:
What Bat-fowling for Offices,
As you must conceiue their Game is all i'thnight,
What calling in question one anothers honesties
Withall what sway they beare i'th Viceroyes Court,
You'd wonder at it:
Twill doe well shortly, can we keepe them off
From being of our Councell of Warre.

SP.SPEAKER: Crisp.
SP.L: Well, I haue vowed,
That I will neuer sit vpon the Bench more,
Vnlesse it be to curbe the insolencies.
Of these women.

SP.SPEAKER: Ario.
SP.L: Well, take it on my word then,
Your place will not long be emptie.
SP.STAGE: Enter Romelio in the habit of a Iew.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Excellently well habited, why me thinks,
That I could play with mine owne shaddow now,
And be a rare Italienated Iew;
To haue as many seuerall change of faces,
As I haue seene caru'd vpon on Cherrystone;
To winde about a man like rotten Iuie,
Eate into him like Quicksiluer, poyson a friend
with pulling but a loose haire frō's beard, or giue a drēch,
He should singer of't nine yeares, and nere complaine,
But in the Spring and Fall, and so the cause
Imputed to the disease naturall, for sleight villanies,
As to coyne money, corrupt Ladies Honours,
Betray a Towne to'th Turke, or make a Bonefire
A'th Christian Nauy, I could settle too't,
As if I had eate a Politician,
And disgested him to nothing but pure blood.
But stay, I loose my selfe, this is the house.
Within there.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Sur.
SP.L: Now sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: You are the men of Art, that as I heare,
Haue the Lord Contarino vnder cure.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Sur.
SP.L: Yes sir, we are his Surgeons,
But he is past all Cure.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Why, is he dead?

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Sur.
SP.L: He is speechlesse sir, and we doe find his wound
So fester'd neere the vitals, all our Art
By warme drinks, cannot cleare th'impostumation,
And hee's so weake, to make
By the Orifix were present death to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom
SP.L: He has made a Will I heare.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Sur.
SP.L: Yes sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom
SP.L: And deputed Iolenta his heyre.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Sur.
SP.L: He has, we are witnesse too't.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom
SP.L: Has not Romelio been with you yet,
To giue you thanks, and ample recompence
For the paines you haue tane.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Sur.
SP.L: Not yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Listen to me Gentlemen, so I protest,
If you will seriously mind your owne good,
I am come about a businesse shall conuey
I arge legacies from Contarino's Will
To both of you.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Sur.
SP.L: How sir?
Why Rom. has the wil, & in that he has giuen vs nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: I pray attend me: I am a Phisician.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Sur.
SP.L: A Phisician? where doe you practise?

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: In Rome.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Sur.
SP.L: O then you haue store of Patients.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Store? why looke you, I can kill my o a month
And worke but i'th forenoones: you will giue me leaue
To iest and be merry with you, but as I said,
All my study has been Phisicke, I am sent
From a noble Roman that is neere a kinne
To Contarino, and that ought indeed,
By the Law of Iliance, be his onely heyre,
To practise his good and yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Both.
SP.L: How, I pray sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: I can by an Extraction which I haue,
Tho he were speechlesse, his eyes set in's head,
His pulses without motion, restore to him
For halfe an houres space, the vse of sense,
And perhaps a little speech: hauing done this,
If we can worke him, as no doubt we shall,
To make another Will, and therein assigne
This Gentleman his Heyre, I will assure you,
Fore I depart this house, ten thousand Duckets,
And then weele pull the pillow from his head,
And let him ne goe whither the Religion sends him
That he died in.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Sur.
SP.L: Will you giue's ten thousand Duckets?

SP.SPEAKER: Rom
SP.L: Vpon my Iewisme.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Sur.
SP.L: Tis a bargaine sir, we are yours:
Here is the Subiect you must worke on.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Well said, you are honest men,
And goe to the businesse roundly: but Gentlemen,
I must vse my Art singly.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Sur.
SP.L: Oh sir, you shall haue all priuacy,

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: And the doores lockt to me.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Sur.
SP.L: At your best pleasure.
Yet for all this, I will not trust this Iew.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Sur.
SP.L: Faith, to say truth,
I doe not like him neither, he looks like a rogue.
This is a fine toy fetch a man to life,
To make a new Will, there's some tricke in't.
Ile be neere you Iew.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Excellent as I would wish: these credulous fooles
Haue giuen me freely what I would haue bought
With a great deale of money. -Softly, her's breuth yet;
Now Ercole, for part of the Reuenge,
Which I haue vow'd for thy vntimely death:
Besides, this politique working of my owne,
That scornes President, why should this great man liue,
And not enioy my sister, as I haue vowed
He neuer shall? Oh, he may alters will
Euery New Moone if he please; to preuent which,
I must put in a strong Caueat. Come forth then
My desperate Steeletto, that may be worne
In a womans haire, and nere discouer'd,
And either would be taken for a Bodkin,
Or a curling yron at most; why tis an engine,
That's onely fit to put in execution Barmotho Pigs,
A most vnmanly weapon,
That steales into a mans life he knowes not how:
O great Caesar, he that past the shocke
Of so many armed Pikes, and poyson'd Darts,
Swords, Slings, and Battleaxes, should at length
Sitting at ease on a cushion, come to dye
By such a Shoo-makers aule as this, his soule et forth
At a hole, no bigger then the incision
Made for a wheal: vos foot, I am horribly angry,
That he should dye so scuruily: yet wherefore
Doe I condemne thee thereof so cruelly?
Yet shake him by the hand, tis to expresse,
That I would neuer haue such weapons vsed,
But in a plot like this, that's treacherous:
Yet this shall prooue most mercifull to thee,
For it shall preserue thee
From dying on a publique Scaffold, and withall
Bring thee an absolute Cure, thus.
So, tis done: and now for my escape.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Sur.
SP.L: You Rogue Mountebanke,
I will try whether your inwards can indure
To be washt in scalding lead.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Hold, I turne Christian.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Sur.
SP.L: Nay prethee bee a Iew still;
I would not haue a Christian be guiltie
Of such a villanous act as this is.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: I am Romelio the Marchant.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Sur.
SP.L: Romelio! you haue prooued your selfe
A cunning Marchant indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: You may reade why I came hither.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Sur.
SP.L: Yes, in a bloudy Roman Letter.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: I did hate this man, each minute of his breath
Was torture to me.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Sur.
SP.L: Had you forborne this act, he had not liu'd
This two houres.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: But he had died then,
And my reuenge vnsatisfied: here's gold;
Neuer did wealthy man purchase the silence
Of a terrible scolding wife at a dearer rate,
Then I will pay for yours: here's your earnest
In a bag of double Duckets.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Sur.
SP.L: Why looke you sir, as I do weigh this busines,
This cannot be counted murder in you by no meanes.
Why tis no more, then should I goe and choke
An Irish man, that were three quarters drownd,
With powring Vsquebath in's throat.

SP.SPEAKER: Ro.
SP.L: You will be secret

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Su.
SP.L: As your soule. (then.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: The west Indies shall sooner want gold, then you

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Su
SP.L: That protestation has the musick of the Mint in't.

SP.SPEAKER: Ro.
SP.P: How vnfortunatly was I surpriz'd, I haue made my selfe a slaue perpetually to these two beggars.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Su.
SP.L: Excellent; by this act he has made his estate ours.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Su.
SP.P: He presently grow a lazy Surgeon, & ride on my foot-cloth; He fetch from him euery eight dayes a policy for a hundred double Duckets; if hee grumble, Ile peach.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Sur.
SP.L: But let's take heed he doe not poyson vs.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Sur.
SP.L: Oh, I will neuer eate nor drinke with him,
Without Vnicornes Horne in a hollow tooth.

SP.SPEAKER: Cont.
SP.L: Oh.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Sur.
SP.L: Did he not groane?

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Sur.
SP.L: Is the wind in that doore still?

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Sur.
SP.L: Ha! come hither, note a strange accident:
His Steele has lighted in the former wound,
And made free passage for the congealed blood;
Obserue in what abundance it deliuers the putrifaction.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Sur.
SP.L: Me thinks he fetches his breath very liuely.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Sur.
SP.L: The hand of heauen is in't,
That his entent to kill him should become
The very direct way to saue his life

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Sur.
SP.L: Why this is like one I haue heard of in England,
Was cured a'th Gowt, by being rackt i'th Tower.
Well, if we can recouer him, here's reward
On both sides: howsoeuer we must be secret.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Sur.
SP.L: We are tyde too't,
When we cure Gentlemen of foule diseases,
They giue vs so much for the cure, and twice as much,
That we doe not blab on't. Come lets to worke roundly,
Heat the Lotion, and bring the Searing.
SP.STAGE: A Table set forth with two Tapers, a Deaths head, a Booke, Iolenta in mourning, Romelio sits by her.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom
SP.L: Why do you grieue thus? take a Looking-glasse,
And see if this sorrow become you; that pale face
Will make men thinke you vsde some Art before,
Some odious painting: Contarino's dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Iol.
SP.L: Oh that he should dye so soone.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Why, I pray tell me,
Is not the shortest feuer the best? and are not bad Playes
The worse for their length?

SP.SPEAKER: Iolen.
SP.L: Adde not to'th ill y'aue done
An odious slander; he stuck i'th eyes a'th Court,
As the most choyce iewell there.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Oh be not angry;
Indeed the Court to well composed nature
Addes much to perfection: for it is or should be,
As a bright Christall, Mirrour to the world,
To dresse it selfe; but I must tell you sister,
If th' excellency of the place could haue wroght saluation,
The Deuill had nere falne from heauen; he was proud,
Leaue vs, leaue vs?
Come, take your seat agen, I haue a plot,
If you will listen to it seriously,
That goes beyond example, it shall breed
Out of the death of these two Noble men,
The aduancement of our House.

SP.SPEAKER: Iol.
SP.L: Oh take heed, a graue is a rotten foundation.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Nay, nay, heare me.
Tis somewhat indirectly, I confesse:
But there is much aduauncement in the world,
That comes in indirectly. I pray mind me:
You are already made by absolute Will,
Contarino's heyre: now, if it can be prooued,
That you haue issue by Lord Ercole,
I will make you inherite his Land too.

SP.SPEAKER: Iol.
SP.L: How's this? issue by him, he dead, and I a Virgin!

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: I know you would wonder how it could be done,
But I haue layd the case so radically,
Not all the Lawyers in Christendome,
Shall finde any the least slaw in't: I haue a Mistris
Of the Order of Saint Clare, a beautious Nun,
Who being cloystred ere she knew the heat,
Her blood would arriue to, had onely time enough
To repent, and idlenesse sufficient
To fall in loue with mee; and to be short,
I haue so much disordered the holy Order,
I haue got this Nun with child.

SP.SPEAKER: Jol.
SP.L: Excellent worke made for a dumbe Mid-wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: I am glad you grow thus pleasant.
Now will I haue you presently giue out,
That you are full two moneths quickned with child
By Ercole, which rumour can beget
No scandall to you, since we will affirme,
The Precontract was so exactly done,
By the same words vsde in the forme of mariage,
That with a little Dispensation,
A money matter, it shall be registred
Absolute Matrimony.

SP.SPEAKER: Iol.
SP.L: So then I conceaue you,
My conceaued child must proue your Bastard.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Right: for at such time
My Mistris fals in labour, you must faine the like.

SP.SPEAKER: Iol.
SP.L: Tis a pretty feat this, but I am not capable of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Not capable?

SP.SPEAKER: Jol.
SP.L: No for the thing you would haue me counterfet,
Is most essentially put in practise: nay, tis done,
I am with child already.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Ha by whom?

SP.SPEAKER: Iol.
SP.L: By Contarino, doe not knit the brow,
The Precontract shall iustifie it, it shall:
Nay, I will get some singular fine Churchman,
Or tho he be a plurall one, shall affirme,
He coupled vs together

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Oh misfortune!
Your child must then be reputed Ercoles.

SP.SPEAKER: Iol.
SP.L: Your hopes are dasht then, since your Votaries issue
Must not inherit the land.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: No matter for that,
So I preserue her fame. I am strangely puzled:
Why, suppose that she be brought abed before you,
And we conceale her issue till the time
Of your deliuery, and then giue out,
That you haue two at a birth, ha, wert not excellent?

SP.SPEAKER: Iol.
SP.L: And what resemblance think you, would they haue
To one another? Twinnes are still alike:
But this is not your ayme, you would haue your child
Inherite Ercoles Land,—Oh my sad soule,
Haue you not made me yet wretched ynough,
But after all this frostie age in youth,
Which you haue witcht vpon me, you will seeke
To poyson my Fame.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: That's done already.

SP.SPEAKER: Iol
SP.L: No sir, I did but faine it,
To a fatall purpose, as I thought.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: What purpose?

SP.SPEAKER: Iol.
SP.L: If you had lou'd or tendred my deare honour,
You would haue lockt your ponyard in my heart,
When I nam'd I was with child; but I must liue
To linger out, till the consumption of my owne
Sorrow kill me.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.P: This will not doe; the Deuill has on the sudden furnisht mee with a rare charme, yet a most vnnaturall falshood: no matter so 'twill take.
SP.L: Stay sister, I would vtter to you a businesse,
But I am very loath: a thing indeed,
Nature would haue compassionately conceal'd,
Till my mothers eyes be closed.

SP.SPEAKER: Iol.
SP.L: Pray what's that sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: You did obserue,
With what a deare regard our mother tendred
The Lord Contarino, yet how passionately
Shee sought to crosse the match: why this was meerely
To blind the eye o'th world; for she did know
That you would marry him, and he was capable
My mother doated vpon him, and it was plotted
Cunningly betweene them, after you were married,
Liuing all three together in one house,
A thing I cannot whisper without horrour:
Why, the malice scarse of Deuils would suggest,
Incontinence 'tweene them two.

SP.SPEAKER: Iol.
SP.L: I remember since his hurt,
Shee has bene very passionately enquiring,
After his health.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Vpon my soule, this Iewell,
With a piece of the holy Crosse in't, this relicke,
SP.P: Vallewed at many thousand crownes, she would haue sent him, lying vpon his death bed.

SP.SPEAKER: Iol.
SP.L: Professing as you say,
Loue to my mother: wherefore did he make
Me his heyre?

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: His Will was made afore he went to fight,
When he was first a Suitor to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Iol.
SP.L: To fight: oh well remembred,
If he lou'd my mother, wherefore did he loose
His life in my quarrell?

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: For the affront sake, a word you vnderstand not,
Because Ercole was pretended Riuall to him,
To cleare your suspition; I was gulld in't too:
Should he not haue fought vpon't,
He had vndergone the censure of a Coward.

SP.SPEAKER: Iol.
SP.L: How came you by this wretched knowledge?

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: His Surgeon ouer-heard it,
As he did sigh it out to his Confessor,
Some halfe houre fore hee died.

SP.SPEAKER: Jol.
SP.L: I would haue the Surgeon hang'd
For abusing Confession, and for making me
So wretched by'th report. Can this be truth?

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: No, but direct falshood,
As euer was banisht the Court: did you euer heare
Of a mother that has kept her daughters husband
For her owne tooth? He fancied you in one kind,
For his lust, and he loued
Our mother in another kind, for her money,
The Gallants fashion right. But come, nere thinke on't,
Throw the fowle to the Deuill that hatcht it, and let this
Bury all ill that's in't, shee is our mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Iol.
SP.L: I neuer did find any thing ith world,
Turne my blood so much as this: here's such a conflict,
Betweene apparant presumption, and vnbeleefe,
That I shall dye in't.
Oh, if there be another world i'th Moone,
As some fantasticks dreame, I could wish all men,
The whole race of them, for their inconstancy,
Sent thither to people that. Why, I protest,
I now affect the Lord Ercoles memory,
Better then the others.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: But were Contarino liuing.

SP.SPEAKER: Iol.
SP.L: I doe call any thing to witnesse,
That the diuine Law prescribed vs
To strengthen an oath, were he liuing and in health,
I would neuer mary with him.
Nay, since I haue found the world
So false to me, Ile be as false to it;
I will mother this child for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Ha?

SP.SPEAKER: Iol.
SP.L: Most certainly it will be guile part of my sorrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom
SP.L: Oh most assuredly, make you smile to thinke,
How many times ith world Lordships descend
To diuers men, that might and truth were knowne
Be heyre, for any thing belongs to'th flesh,
As well to the Turkes richest Eunuch.

SP.SPEAKER: Iol.
SP.L: But doe you not thinke
I shall haue a horrible strong breath now.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Why?

SP.SPEAKER: Iol.
SP.L: Oh, with keeping your counsel, tis so terrible foule,

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Come, come, come,
You must leaue these bitter flashes.

SP.SPEAKER: Iol.
SP.L: Must I dissemble dishonestie? you haue diuers
Counterfeit honestie: but I hope here's none
Will take exceptions; I now must practise
The art of a great bellyed woman, and goe faine
Their qualmes and swoundings.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.P: Eat vnripe fruit, and Oatmeale, to take away your colour.

SP.SPEAKER: Iol.
SP.L: Dine in my bed some two houres after noone.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: And when you are vp,
Make to your petticoat a quilted preface,
To aduance your belly.

SP.SPEAKER: Iol.
SP.L: I haue a strange conceit now.
I haue knowen some women when they were with child,
Haue long'd to beat their Husbands: what if I,
To keepe decorum, exercise my longing
Vpon my Taylor that way, and noddle him soundly,
Heele make the larger Bill for't.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Ile get one shall be as tractable too't as Stockfish.

SP.SPEAKER: Iol.
SP.L: Oh my phantasticall sorrow,
Cannot I now be miserable enough,
Vnlesse I weare a pyde fooles coat:
Nay worse, for when our passions
Such giddy and vncertaine changes breed,
We are neuer well, till we are mad indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: So, nothing in the world could haue done this,
But to beget in her a strong distaste
Of the Lord Contarino: oh Ielousie,
How violent, especially in women,
How often has it raisd the deuil vp in forme of a law case!
My especiall care must be, to nourish craftily this fiend,
Tweene the mother and the daughter, that the deceit
Be not perceiued. My next taske, that my sister,
After this suppofed child-birth, be perswaded
To enter into Religion: tis concluded,
Shee must neuer marry; so I am left guardian
To her estate: and lastly, that my two Surgeons
Be waged to the East Indies: let them prate,
When they are beyond the Lyne; the Callenture,
Or the Scuruy, or the Indian Pox, I hope,
Will take order for their comming backe.
Oh heere's my mother: I ha strange newes for you,
My sister is with child.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo
SP.L: I doe looke now for some great misfortunes
To follow: for indeed mischiefes,
Are like the Visits of Franciscan Fryers,
They neuer come to pray vpon vs single.
In what estate left you Contarino?

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Strange, that you can skip
From the former sorrow to such a question!
Ile tell you, in the absence of his Surgeon,
My charitie did that for him in a trice,
They would haue done at leasure, and been paid for't.
I haue killed him.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: I am twentie yeares elder since you last opened your lips.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Ha?

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.L: You haue giuen him the wound you speake of,
Quite thorow your mothers heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: I will heale it presently mother: for this sorrow
Belongs to your errour: you would haue him liue,
Because you thinke hee's father of the child;
But Iolenta vowes by all the rights of Truth,
Tis Ercole's: it makes me smile to thinke,
How cunningly my sister could be drawen
To the Contract, and yet how familiarly
To his bed. Doues neuer couple
Without a kind of murmur.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: Oh, I am very sicke.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Your old disease, when you are grieu'd,
You are troubled with the Mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: I am rapt with the Mother indeed,
That I euer bore such a sonne.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Pray tend my sister,
I am infinitely full of businesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo
SP.L: Stay you will mourne for Contarino.

SP.SPEAKER: Ro.
SP.L: Oh by all meanes, tis fit, my sister is his heire.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: I will make you chiefe mourner, beleeue it.
Neuer was woe like mine: oh that my care,
And absolute study to preserue his life,
Should be his absolute ruine. Is he gone then?
