There is no plague i'th world can be compared
To impossible desire; for they are plagued
In the desire it selfe: neuer, oh neuer
'Shall I behold him liuing, in whose life
I liued farre sweetlier then in mine owne.
A precise curiositie has vndone me; why, did I not
Make my loue knowne directly? t'had not been
Beyond example, for a Matron
To affect i'th honourable way of Marriage,
So youthfall a person: oh I shall runne mad,
For as we loue our youngest children best:
So the last fruit of our affection,
Where euer we bestow it, is most strong,
Most violent, most vnresistable,
Since tis indeed our latest Hardest-home,
Last merryment Fore Winter; and we widdowes,
As men report, of our best Picture-makers,
We loue the piece we are in hand with better,
Then all the excellent worke we haue done before,
And my sonne has depriu'd me of all this. Ha my sonne,
Ile be a fury to him, like an Amazon Lady,
Ide cut off his right pap, that gaue him sucke,
To shoot him dead. Ile no more tender him,
Then had a Wolfe stolne to my tear i'th night,
And robb'd me of my milke: nay, such a creature
I should loue better farre. -Ha, ha, what say you?
I doe talke to somewhat, me thinks; it may be
My euill Genius. Doe not the Bells ring?
I haue a strange noyse in my head: oh, fly in pieces,
Come age, and wither me into the malice
Of those that haue been happy, let me haue
One propertie more then the Deuill of Hell,
Let me enuy the pleasure of youth heartily,
Let me in this life feare no kinde of ill,
That haue no good to hope for: let me dye
In the distraction of that worthy Princesse,
Who loathed food, and sleepe, and ceremony,
For thought of loosing that braue Gentleman,
She would faine haue saued, had not a false countenance,
Let me sinke, where neither man,
Nor memory may euer find me.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: This is a priuate way which I command,
As her Confessor. I would not haue you seene yet,
Till I prepare her. Peace to you Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: Ha?

SP.SPEAKER: Cap
SP.L: You are wel imployd, I hope; the best pillow i'th.
World for this your contemplation, is the earth,
And the best obiect heauen.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: I am whispering to a dead friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: And I am come
To bring you tidings of a friend not dead,
Reserued to life againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: Say sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: One whom I dare presume, next to your children,
You tendred aboue life.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: Heauen will not suffer me vtterly to be lost.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: For hee should haue been
Your sonne in Law, miraculously saued,
When Surgery gaue him ore.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.L: Oh, may you liue
To winne many soules to heauen, worthy sir,
That your crowne may be the greater. Why my sonne
made me beleeue he stole into his chamber,
And ended that which Ercole began
By a deadly stabb in's heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Erco.
SP.L: Alas, shee mistakes,
Tis Contarino she wishes liuing; but I must fasten
On her last words, for my owne safetie.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: Where, oh where shall I meet this comfort?

SP.SPEAKER: Erco.
SP.L: Here in the vowed comfort of your daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Oh I am dead agen, instead of the man, you pre∣sent me the graue swallowed him.

SP.SPEAKER: Erco.
SP.L: Collect your selfe, good Lady,
Would you behold braue Contarino liuing?
There cannot be a nobler Chronicle
Of his good then my selfe: if you would view him dead,
I will present him to you bleeding fresh,
In my penitency.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: Sir, you doe onely liue,
To redeeme another ill you haue committed,
That my poore innocent daughter perish not,
By your vild sinne, whom you haue got with child.

SP.SPEAKER: Erco.
SP.L: Here begin a I my compassion: oh poore soule!
Shee is with child by Contarino, and he dead,
By whom should she preerue her fame to'th world,
But by my selfe that loued her boue the world?
There neuer was a way more honourable,
To exercise my vertue, then to father it,
And preserue her credit, and to marry her.
Ile suppose her Contarino's widdow, bequeath'd to me
Vpon his Death: for sure shee was his wife,
But that the Ceremony a'th Church was wanting.
Report this to her, Madam, and withall,
That neuer father did conceaue more ioy
For the birth of an heyre, then I to vnderstand,
Shee had such confidence in me. I will not now
Presse a Visit vpon her, till you haue prepar'd her:
For I doe reade in your distraction,
Should I be brought a'th sudden to her presence,
Either the hastie fright, or else the shame
May blast the fruit within her. I will leaue you,
To commend as loyall faith and seruice to her,
As ere heart harbour'd; by my hope of blisse,
I neuer liu'd to doe good act but this.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: Withall and you be wise,
Remember what the mother has reueal'd
Of Romelio's treachery.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.L: A most noble fellow in his loyaltie.
I read what worthy comforts I haue lost
In my deare Contarino, and all addes
To my dispayre.—Within there.
Fetch the picture hangs in my inner closet. I remember,
I let a word slip of Romelio's practise
At the Surgeons: no matter I can salue it,
I haue deeper vengeance that's preparing for him,
To let him liue and kill him that's reuenge
I meditate vpon.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: So, hang it vp.
I was enioyned by thepartie ought that picture,
Fortie yeares since, euer when I was vext,
To looke vpon that: what was his meaning in't,
I know not, but me thinkesvpon the sudden,
It has furnisht me with mischiefe such a plot,
As neuer mother dreamt of Here begines
My part i'th play: my sonnes estate is sunke,
By losse at sea and he has nothing left,
But the Land his father left him. I is concluded,
The Law shall vndoe him Come hither,
I haue a weightie secret to impart,
But I would haue thee first confirme to mee,
How I may trust, that thou canst keepe my counsell,
Beyond death.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: Why Mistris, tis your onely way,
To enioyne me first that I reueale to you
The worst act I ere did in all my life:
So one secret shall bind one another.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: Thou instru'st me
Most ingenuously, for indeed it is not fit,
Where any act is plotted, that is nought,
Any of counsell to it should be good,
And in a thousand ils haue hapt i'th world,
The intelligence of one anothers shame,
Haue wrought farre more effectually then the tye
Of Conscience, or Religion.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: But thinke not, Mistris,
That any sinne which euer I committed,
Did concerne you, for proouing false in one thing,
You were a foole, if euer you would trust me
In the least matter of weight.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo
SP.L: Thou hast liued with me
Thse fortie yeares; we haue growne old together,
As many Ladies and their women doe,
With talking nothing, and with doing lesse:
We haue spent our life in that which least concernes life,
Only in putting on our clothes: and now I thinke on't,
I haue been a very courtly Mistris to thee, (time,
I haue giuen thee good words, but no deeds, now's the
To requite all; my sonne has sixe Lordships left him.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: Tis truth.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: But he cannot liue foure dayes to enioy them.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: Haue you poysoned him?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: No, the poyson is yet but brewing.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: You must minister it to him with all priuacie.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: Priuacie? It shall be giuen him
In open Court, Ile make him swallow it
Before the Iudges face: if he be Master
Of poore ten arpines of land fortie houres longer,
Let the world repute me an honest woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: So 'twill I hope.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: Oh thou canst not conceiue
My vnimitable plot; let's to my ghostly Father,
Were first I will haue thee make a promise
To keepe my counsell, and then I will employ thee
In such a subtill combination,
Which will require to make the practise fit,
Foure Deuils, fiue Aduocates to a womans wit.

SP.STAGE: Enter Leoonora, Sanitonella at one doore, Winifrid, Register: at the other Ariosto

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.L: Take her into your Office sir, shee has that in her
Belly, will drie vp your inke I can tell you.
This is the man that is your learned Councell,
A fellow that will trowle it off with tongue:
He neuer goes without Restoratiue powder
Of the lungs of Fox in's pocket, and Malligo Reasins
To make him long winded. Sir, this Gentlewoman
Intreats your Counsell in an honest cause,
Which please you sir, this Briefe, my owne poore labor
Will giue you light of.

SP.SPEAKER: Ario.
SP.L: Doe you call this a Briefe?
Here's as I weigh them, some fourescore sheets of paper.
What would they weigh if there were cheese
Wrapt in them, or Figdates.

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.L: Ioy come to you, you are merry;
We call this but a Briefe in our Office.
The scope of the businesse lyes ith Margent sheet.

SP.SPEAKER: Ario.
SP.L: Me thinks you prate too much.
I neuer could endure an honest cause
With a long Prologue too't.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon
SP.L: You trouble him.

SP.SPEAKER: Ar.
SP.L: Whats here? oh strange; I haue liued this 60 yeres,
Yet in all my practise neuer did shake hands
With a cause so odious. Sirrah, are you her knaue?

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.L: No sir, I am a Clarke.

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.L: Why you whorson fogging Rascall,
Are there not whores enow for Presentations,
Of Ouerseers, wrong the will o'th Dead,
Oppressions of Widdowes, or young Orphans,
Wicked Diuerses, or your vicious cause
Of Plus quam satis, to content a woman,
But you must find new stratagems, new pursuits,
Oh women, as the Ballet liues to tell you,
What will you shortly come to?

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.L: Your Fee is ready sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.L: The Deuill take such Fees,
And all such Suits i'thtayle of thee; see the slaue
Has writ false Latine: sirrah Ignorance,
Were you euer at the Vniuersitie?

SP.SPEAKER: San
SP.L: Neuer sir:
It is well knowne to diuers I haue Commenc't
In a Pewe of our Office.

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.L: Where, in a Pew of your Office?

SP.SPEAKER: San
SP.L: I haue been dry-foundred with't this foure yeares,
Seldome found Non resident from my deske.

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.L: Non resident Subsumner:
Ile teare your Libell for abusing that word,
By vertue of the Clergie.

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.L: What doe you meane sir?
It cost me foure nights labour.

SP.SPEAKER: Ario.
SP.L: Hadst thou been drunke so long,
T'hadst done our Court better Seruice.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo
SP.L: Sir, you doe forget your grauitie, me thinks.

SP.SPEAKER: Ario.
SP.L: Cry ye mercy, doe I so?
And as I take it, you doe very little remember,
Either womanhood, or Christianitie: why doe ye meddle
With that seducing knaue, that's good for nought,
Vnlesse 'the to fill the Office full of Fleas,
Or a Winter itch, weares that spatious Inkehorne
All a Vacation onely to cure Tetters,
And his Penknife to weed Cornes from the splay toes,
Of the right worshipfull of the Office.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: You make bold with me sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ario.
SP.L: Woman, yare mad, Ile swear't, & haue more need
Of a Physician then a Lawyer.
The melancholly humour flowes in your face,
Your painting cannot hide it: such vildsuits
Disgrace our Courts, and these make honest Lawyers
Stop their own eares, whilst they p'ead & thats the reason
Your yonger men that haue good conscience,
weare such large Night-caps; go old woman, go pray,
For Lunacy, or else the Deuill himselfe
Has tane possession of thee; may like cause
In any Christian Court neuer find name:
Bad Suits, and not the Law, bred the Lawes shame.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.L: Sure the old man's franticke.

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.L: Plague on's gowtie fingers,
Were all of his mind, to entertaine no suits,
But such they thought were hotest, sure our Lawyers
Would not purchase halfe so fast:
But here's the man,
Learned Seignior Contilupo, here's a fellow
Of another piece beleeue't, I must make shift
With the foule Copie.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Businesse to me?

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.L: To you sir, from this Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: She is welcom.

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.L: Tis a foule Copy sir, youle hardly read it,
There's twenty double duckets, can you reade sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Exceeding well, very, very exceeding well.

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.L: This man will be faued, he can read; Lord, Lord,
To see, what money can doe, be the hand neuer so foule,
Somewhat will be pickt out on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Is not this Viuere honeste?

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.L: No, that's strucke out sir;
And where euer you find viuere honeste in these papers,
Giue it a dash sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: I shall be mindfull of it:
In troth you write a pretty Secretary,
Your Secretary hand euer takes best in mine opinion.

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.L: Sir, I haue been in France,
And there beleeue't your Court hand generally,
Takes beyond thought.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Euen as a man is traded in't.

SP.SPEAKER: Sa.
SP.L: That I could not think of this vertuous Gentleman
Before I went to'th tother Hogg-rubber.
Why this was wont to giue young Clerkes halfe fees,
To helpe him to Clyents. Your opinion in the Case sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: I am strucke with wonder almost extaside,
With this most goodly Suite.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.L: It is the fruit of a most heartie penitence.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Tis a Case shall leaue a President to all the world,
In our succeeding Annals, and deserues
Rather a spatious publike Theater,
Then a pent Court for Audence; it shall teach
All Ladies the right path to rectisie their issue.

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.L: Loe you, here's a man of comfort.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: And you shall goe vnto a peacefull graue,
Discharg'd of such a guilt, as would haue layne
Howling for euer at your wounded heart,
And rose with you to Iudgement. (of Iudgment.

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.L: Oh giue me such a Lawyer, as wil think of the day

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: You must vrge the businesse against him
As spightfully as may be.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Doubt not. What is he summon'd?

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.L: Yes, & the Court will sit within this halfe houre.
Peruse your Notes, you haue very short warning.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Neuer feare you that:
Follow me worthy Lady, and make account
This Suite is ended already.
SP.STAGE: Enter Officers preparing seats for the Iudges, to them Ercole muffled.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Of.
SP.L: You would haue a priuate seat sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Erc.
SP.L: Yes sir.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Of.
SP.L: Here's a Closst belongs to'th Court,
Where you may heare all vnseene.

SP.SPEAKER: Er.
SP.L: I thank you; there's money.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Of.
SP.L: I giue you your thanks agen sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cont.
SP.L: Ist possible Romelio's perswaded,
You are gone to the East Indies.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Sur.
SP.L: Most confidently.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: But doe you meane to goe?

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Su.
SP.L: How? goe to the East Indies?
SP.P: And so many Hollanders gone to fetch sauce for their pic∣keld Herrings; some haue bene pepperd there too lately, but I pray, being thus well recouerd of your wounds,
SP.L: Why doe you not reucale yourselfe?

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: That my fayre Iolenta should be rumor'd
To be with child by noble Ercole,
Makes me expect to what a violent issue
These passages will come. I heare her brother
Is marying the Infant shee goes with, fore it be borne,
As if it be a Daughter,
To the Duke of Austrias Nephew; if a Sonne,
Into the Noble ancient Family
Of the Palaafini: Hee's a subtill Deuill.
And I doe wonder what strange Suite in Law,
Has hapt betweene him and's mother.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Sur.
SP.L: Tis whisperd' mong the Lawyers,
'Twill vndoe him for euer.

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.L: Doe you heare Officers?
You must take speciall care, that you let in
No Brachigraphy men, to take notes.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Of.
SP.L: No sir?

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.L: By no meanes,
We cannot haue a Cause of any fame,
But you must haue scuruy pamphlets, and lewd Ballets
Engendred of it presently.

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.L: Haue you broke fast yet?

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: Not I sir.

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.L: 'Twas very ill done of you:
For this cause will be long a pleading; but not matter,
I haue a modicum in my Buckram bagg,
To stop your stomacke.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: What ist? Greene ginger?

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.L: Greene ginger, nor Pellitory of Spaine neither,
Yet 'twill stop a hollow tooth better then either of them.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: Pray what ist?

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.L: Looke you,
It is a very louely Pudding-pye,
Which we Clerkes find great reliefe in.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: I shall haue no stomacke.

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.L: No matter and you haue not, I may pleasure
Some of our Learned Councell with't; I haue done it
Many a time and often, when a Cause
Has prooued like an after-game at Irish.
SP.STAGE: Enter Crispiano like a Iudge, with another Iudge, Contilupo, and another Lawyer at one Barre, Romelio, Ariosto, at another, Leonora with a blacke vaileouer her, and Iulio.

SP.SPEAKER: Crisp.
SP.L: Tis a strange Suite, is Leonora come.

SP.SPEAKER: Conti.
SP.L: She's here my Lord; make way there for the Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Crisp.
SP.L: Take off her Vaile: it seemes she is ashamed
To looke her cause i'th face.

SP.SPEAKER: Contil.
SP.L: Shee's sicke, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.L: Shee's mad my Lord, & would be kept more dark.
SP.P: By your fauour sir, I haue now occasion to be at your el∣bow, and within this halfe houre shall intreat you to bee angry, very angry.

SP.SPEAKER: Crisp.
SP.L: Is Romelio come?

SP.SPEAKER: Rom
SP.L: I am here my Lord, and call'd I doe protest,
To answer what I know not, for as yet
I am wholly ignorant, of what the Court
Will charge me with.

SP.SPEAKER: Crisp.
SP.L: I assure you, the proceeding
Is most vnequall then, for I perceiue,
The Councell of the aduerse partie furnisht
With full Instruction.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Pray my Lord, who is my accuser?

SP.SPEAKER: Crisp.
SP.L: Tis your mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Shee has discouered Contarino's murder:
If shee prooue so vnnaturall, to call
My life in question, I am arm'd to suffer
This to end all my losses.

SP.SPEAKER: Crisp.
SP.L: Sir, we will doe you this fauour,
You shall heare the Accusation,
Which being knowne, we will adiourne the Court,
Till a fortnight hence, you may prouide your Counsell.

SP.SPEAKER: Ario.
SP.L: I aduise you, take their proffer,
Or else the Lunacy runnes in a blood,
You are more mad then shee.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: What are you sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Ario.
SP.L: An angry fellow that would doe thee good,
For goodnesse sake it selfe, I doe protest,
Neither for loue nor money.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Prethee stand further, I shal gall your gowt else.

SP.SPEAKER: Ar.
SP.L: Come, come, I know you for an East Indy Marchant,
You haue a spice of pride in you still.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: My Lord, I am so strengthned in my innocence,
For any the least shaddow of a crime,
Committed gainst my mother, or the world,
That shee can charge me with, here doe I make it
My humble suite, onely this houre and place,
May giue it as full hearing, and as free,
And vnrestrain'd a Sentence.

SP.SPEAKER: Cri.
SP.L: Be not too confident you haue cause to feare.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Let feare dwell with Earth-quakes,
Shipwracks at Sea, or Prodegies in heauen,
I cannot set my selfe so many fathome
Beneath the haight of my true heart, as feare.

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.L: Very fine words I assure you, if they were to any

SP.SPEAKER: Cri.
SP.L: Well, haue your intreatie: (purpose,
And if your owne credulitie vndoe you,
Blame not the Court hereafter: fall to your Plea.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: May it please your Lordsh. & the reuerend Court,
To giue me leaue to open to you a Case
So rare, so altogether voyd of President,
That I doe challenge all the spacious Volumes,
Of the whole Ciuill Law to shew the like.
We are of Councell for this Gentlewoman,
We haue receiu'd our Fee, yet the whole course
Of what we are to speake, is quite against her,
Yet weele deserue our fee too. There stands one,
Romelio the Marchant; I will name him to you,
Without either title or addition:
For those false beames of his supposed honour,
As voyd of true heat, as are all painted fires,
Or Glow-wormes in the darke, suite him all basely,
As if he had bought his Gentry from the Herauld,
With money got by extortion: I will first
Produce this Aesops Crow, as he stands forfeit,
For the long vse of his gay borrowed plumes,
And then let him hop naked: I come to'th poynt,
T'as been a Dreame in Naples, very neere
This eight and thirtie yeares, that this Romelio,
Was nobly descended, he has rankt himselfe
With the Nobilitie, shamefully vsurpt
Their place, and in a kind of lawcy pride,
Which like to Mushromes, euer grow most ranke,
When they do spring from dung-hills, sought to oresway,
The Fliski, the Grimaldi, Dori,
And all the ancient pillars of our State;
View now what he is come to: this poore thing
Without a name, this Cuckow hatcht ith nest
Of a Hedge-sparrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom
SP.L: Speakes he all this to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.L: Onely to you sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: I doe not aske thee, prethee hold thy prating.

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.L: Why very good, you will be presently
As angry as I could wish.

SP.SPEAKER: Contil
SP.L: What title shall I set to this base coyne;
He has no name, and for's aspect he seemes,
A Gyant in a May-game, that within
Is nothing but a Porter' Ile vndertake,
He had as good haue traueld all his life
With Gypsies: I will sell him to any man
For an hundred Chickeens, and he that buyes him of me,
Shall loose byth hand too.

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.L: Loe, what you are come too:
You that did scorne to trade in any thing;
But Gold or Spices, or your Cochineele,
He rates you now at poore Iohn.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Out vpon thee, I would thou wert of his fide,

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.L: Would you so?

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: The deuill and thee together on each hand,
To prompt the Lawyers memory when he founders.

SP.SPEAKER: Cris
SP.L: Signior Contilupo, the Court holds it fit,
You leaue this stale declaiming 'gainst the person,
And come to the matter.

SP.SPEAKER: Cont.
SP.L: Now I shall my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Cris.
SP.L: It showes a poore malicious eloquence,
And it is strange, men of your grauitie
Will not forgoe it: verely, I presume,
If you but heard your selfe speaking with my eares,
Your phrase would be more modest.

SP.SPEAKER: Contil.
SP.L: Good my Lord, be assured,
I will leaue all circumstance, and come toth purpose:
This Romelio is a Bastard.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: How, a Bastard? Oh mother,
Now the day begins grow hote on your side.

SP.SPEAKER: Contil.
SP.L: Why shee is your accuser.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.P: I had forgot that; was my father maried to any other woman, at the time of my begetting?

SP.SPEAKER: Contil.
SP.L: That's not the businesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: I turne me then to you that were my mother,
But by what name I am to call you now,
You must instruct me: were you euer marryed
To my father?

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.L: To my shame I speake it, neuer.

SP.SPEAKER: Crisp.
SP.L: Not to Franscisco Romelio?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: May it please your Lordships,
To him I was, but he was not his father.

SP.SPEAKER: Cont.
SP.L: Good my Lord, giue vs leaue in a few words,
To expound the Riddle, and to make it plaine,
Without the least of scruple: for I take it,
There cannot be more lawfull proofe i'th world,
Then the oath of the mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Cris.
SP.L: Well then, to your proofes, and be not tedious.

SP.SPEAKER: Contil.
SP.L: Ile conclude in a word:
Some nine and thirtie yeares since, which was the time,
This woman was maryed, Francisco Romelio,
This Gentlemans putatiue father, and her husband
Being not married to her past a fortnight,
Would needs goe trauell; did so, and continued
In France and the Low-Countries eleuen monthes:
Take speciall note o'th time, I beseech your Lordship,
For it makes much to'th businesse: in his absence
He left behind to soiourne at his house
A Spanish Gentleman, a fine spruce youth
By the Ladies confession, and you may be sure
He was no Eunuch neither; he was one
Romelio loued very dearely, as oft haps,
No man aliue more welcome to the husband
Then he that makes him Cuckold.
This Gentleman I say,
Breaking all Lawes of Hospitalitie,
Got his friends wife with child, a full two moneths
Fore the husband returned.

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.L: Good sir, forget not the Lambskin.

SP.SPEAKER: Contil.
SP.L: I warrant thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Sa.
SP.L: I wil pinch by the buttock, to put you in mind of't.

SP.SPEAKER: Contil.
SP.L: Prethee hold thy prating.
What's to be practis'd now my Lord? Marry this,
Romelio being a yong nouice, not acquainted
With this precedence, very innocently
Returning home from trauell, finds his wife
Growne an excellent good Huswife, for she had set
Her women to spin Flax, and to that vse,
Had in a study which was built of stone,
Stor'd vp at least an hundreth waight of flaxe:
Marry such a threed as was to be spun from the flax,
I thinke the like was neuer heard of.

SP.SPEAKER: Crisp.
SP.L: What was that?

SP.SPEAKER: Contil.
SP.L: You may be certaine, shee would lose no time,
In braging that her Husband had got vp
Her belly: to be short, at seuen moneths end,
Which was the time of her deliuery,
And when shee felt her selfe to fall in trauell,
Shee makes her Wayting woman, as by mischance,
Set fire to the flax, the flight whereof,
As they pretend, causes this Gentlewoman
To fall in paine, and be deliuered
Eight weekes asore her reckoning.

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.L: Now sir, remember the Lambeskin.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: The Midwife strait howles out, there was no hope
Of th'infants life, swaddles it in a stead Lambeskin,
As a Bird hatcht too early, makes it vp
With three quarters of a face, that made it looke
Like a Changeling, cries out to Romelio,
To haue it Christned, least it should depart
Without that it came for: and thus are many seru'd,
That take care to get Gossips for those children,
To which they might be Godfathers themselues,
And yet be no arch-Puritans neither.

SP.SPEAKER: Crisp.
SP.L: No more.

SP.SPEAKER: Ar.
SP.P: Pray my Lord giue him way, you spoile his oratory else: thus would they iest were they feed, to open their sisters cases.

SP.SPEAKER: Crisp.
SP.L: You haue vrged enough;
You first affirme, her husband was away from her
Eleuen moneths.

SP.SPEAKER: Contil.
SP.L: Yes my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Crisp.
SP.L: And at seuen moneths end,
After his returne shee was deliuered
Of this Romelio, and had gone her full time.

SP.SPEAKER: Contil.
SP.L: True my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Crisp.
SP.L: So by this account this Gentleman was begot,
In his supposed fathers absence.

SP.SPEAKER: Contil.
SP.L: You haue it fully.

SP.SPEAKER: Crisp.
SP.L: A most strange Suite this, tis beyond example,
Either time past, or present; for a woman,
To publish her owne dishonour voluntarily,
Without being called in question, some fortie yeares
After the sinne committed, and her Councell
To inlarge the offence with as much Oratory,
As euer I did heare them in my life,
Defend a guiltie woman; tis most strange:
Or why with such a poysoned violence
Should shee labour her soones vndoing: we obserue
Obedience of creatures to the Law of Nature,
Is the stay of the whole world; here that Law is broke,
For though our Ciuill Law makes difference
Tween the base, and the ligitimate; compassionat Nature
Makes them equall, nay, shee many times preferres them.
I pray resolue me sir, haue not you and your mother
Had some Suite in Law together lately?

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: None my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Cris.
SP.L: No? no contention about parting your goods?

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Not any.

SP.SPEAKER: Cris.
SP.L: No flaw, no vnkindnesse?

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: None that euer arriued at my knowledge.

SP.SPEAKER: Cris.
SP.L: Bethink your selfe, this cannot chuse but sauour
Of a womans malice deeply; and I feare,
Y'are practiz'd vpon most deuillishly.
How hapt Gentlewoman, you reueal'd this no sooner?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: While my husband liued, my Lord, I durst not.

SP.SPEAKER: Cris.
SP.L: I should rather aske you, why you reueale it now?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo
SP.L: Because my Lord, I loath'd that such a sinne
Should lie smotherd with me in my graue; my penitence,
Though to my shame, preferres the reuealing of it
Boue worldly reputation.

SP.SPEAKER: Cris.
SP.L: Your penitence?
Might not your penitence haue beene as hartie,
Though it had neuer summon'd to the Court
Such a conflux of people.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.L: Indeed I might haue confest it,
Priuately toth Church, I grant; but you know repentance
Is nothing without satisfaction.

SP.SPEAKER: Crisp.
SP.L: Satisfaction? why your Husbands dead,
What satisfaction can you make him?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo
SP.L: The greatest satisfaction in the world, my Lord,
To restore the land toth right heire, & thats my daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Crisp.
SP.L: Oh shee's straight begot then.

SP.SPEAKER: Ario
SP.L: Very well, may it please this honourable Court,
If he be a bastard, and must forfeit his land for't,
She has prooued her selfe a strumpet, and must loose
Her Dower, let them goe a begging together.

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.L: Who shall pay vs our Fees then?

SP.SPEAKER: Cris.
SP.L: Most iust.

SP.SPEAKER: Ario
SP.L: You may see now what an old house
You are like to pull ouer your head, Dame.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Could I conceiue this Publication
Grew from a heartie penitence, I could beare
My vndoing the more patiently; but my Lord,
There is no reason, as you sayd euen now,
To satisfie me: but this suite of hers
Springs from a deuillish malice, and lier pretence,
Of a grieued Conscience, and Religion,
Like to the horrid Powder-Treason in England,
Has a most bloody vnnaturall reuenge
Hid vnder it: Oh the violencies of women!
Why they are creatures made vp and compounded
Of all monsters, poysoned Myneralls,
And sorcerous Herbes that growes.

SP.SPEAKER: Ario.
SP.L: Are you angry yet?

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Would men expresse a bad one,
Let him forsake all naturall example,
And compare one to another; they haue no more mercy,
Then minous fires in great tempests.

SP.SPEAKER: Ario.
SP.L: Take heed you doe not cracke your voice sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Hard hearted creatures good for nothing else,
But to winde dead bodies.

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.L: Yes, to weaue seaming lace with the bones of their
SP.P: Husbands that were long since buried, and curse them when they tangle.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Yet why doe I
Take Bastardy so distastfully, when i'th world,
A many things that are essentiall parts
Of greatnesse, are but by-slips, and are father'd
On the wrong parties.
Preferment in the world a many times,
Basely begotten: nay, I haue obseru'd
The immaculate Iustice of a poore mans cause,
In such a Court as this, has not knowen whom
To call Father, which way to direct it selfe
For Compassion: but I forget my temper,
Onely that I may stop that Lawyers throat,
I doe beseech the Court, and the whole world,
They will not thinke the baselyer of me,
For the vice of a mother: for that womans sinne,
To which you all dare sweare when it was done,
I would not giue my consent.

SP.SPEAKER: Cris.
SP.L: Stay, heere's an Accusation,
But here's no proofe; what was the Spanyards name
You accuse of adultery?

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Don Crispiano, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Crisp.
SP.L: What part of Spaine was he borne in?

SP.SPEAKER: Contil.
SP.L: In Castile.

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.L: This may proue my father.

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.L: And my Master, my Clyent's spoyl'd then.

SP.SPEAKER: Cris.
SP.L: I knew that Spanyard well: if you be a Bastard,
Such a man being your father, I dare vouch you
A Gentleman, and in that Signiour Contilupo,
Your Oratory went a little too farre.
When doe wee name Don Iohn of Austria,
The Emperours sonne, but with reuerence:
And I haue knowne in diuers Families,
The Bastards the greater spirits; but to'th purpose,
What time was this Gentleman begot?
And be sure you lay your time right.

SP.SPEAKER: Ario.
SP.L: Now the mettall comes to the Touchstone.

SP.SPEAKER: Contil.
SP.L: In Anno seuentie one, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Crisp
SP.L: Very well, seuentie one:
The Battell of Lepanto was fought in't,
A most remarkeable time, 'twill lye for no mans pleasure▪
And what proofe is there more then the affirmation of the
Mother, of this corporall dealing?

SP.SPEAKER: Contil.
SP.P: The deposition of a Wayting-woman serued her the same time.

SP.SPEAKER: Crisp.
SP.L: Where is shee?

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Where is our Solicitor with the Waitingwoman?

SP.SPEAKER: Ario.
SP.L: Roome for the bagge and baggage.

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.L: Here my Lord, Oretenus.

SP.SPEAKER: Crisp.
SP.L: And what can you say Gentlewoman?

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: Please your Lordship, I was the partie that dealt
In the businesse and brought them together.

SP.SPEAKER: Crisp.
SP.L: Well.

SP.SPEAKER: Win
SP.L: And conueyed letters betweene them. (house?

SP.SPEAKER: Cr.
SP.L: What needed letters, when tis said he lodg'd in her

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: A running Ballad now and then to her Violl,
For he was neuer well, but when he was fidling.

SP.SPEAKER: Crisp.
SP.P: Speake to the purpose, did you euer know them bed together?

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: No my Lord,
But I haue brought him to the bed side.

SP.SPEAKER: Crisp.
SP.L: That was somewhat neere to the busines;
And what, did you helpe him off with his shooes?

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: He wore no shooes, an't please you my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Cris.
SP.L: No? what then, Pumpes?

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: Neither.

SP.SPEAKER: Crisp.
SP.L: Boots were not fit for his iourney.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: He wore Tennis-court woollen slippers,
For feare of creaking sir, and making a noyse,
To wake the rest o'th house.

SP.SPEAKER: Crisp.
SP.L: Well, and what did he there,
In his Tennis-court woollen slippers?

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: Please your Lordship, question me in Latin,
For the cause is very foule; the Examiner o'th Court
Was faine to get it out of me alone i'th Counting-house,
Cause he would not spoyle the youth o'th Office.

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.L: Here's a Latin spoone, and a long one,
To feed with the Deuill.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: Ide be loth to be ignorant that way,
For I hope to marry a Proctor, & take my pleasure abroad
At the Commencements with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Ario.
SP.L: Come closer to the businesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: I wil come as close as modesty will giue me leaue.
Truth is, euery morning when hee lay with her,
I made a Caudle for him, by the appoyntment
Of my Mistris, which he would still refuse,
And call for small drinke.

SP.SPEAKER: Crisp.
SP.L: Small drinke?

SP.SPEAKER: Ario.
SP.L: For a Iulipe.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: And said he was wondrous thirstie.

SP.SPEAKER: Crisp.
SP.L: What's this to the purpose?

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: Most effectuall, my Lord.
I haue heard them laugh together extreamely,
And the Curtaine rods fall from the tester of the bed,
And he nere came from her, but hee thrust money in my
hand; and once in truth, he would haue had some dealing
with mee, which I tooke; he thought 'twould be the onely
way ith world to make me keepe counsell the better.

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.L: That's a stinger, tis a good wench, be not daunted.

SP.SPEAKER: Cri.
SP.L: Did you euer find the print of two in the bed?

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: What a questions that to be askt, may it please your
Lordsh▪ tis to be thought he lay nearer to her then so.

SP.SPEAKER: Crisp.
SP.L: What age are you of Gentlewoman?

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: About six and fortie, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Crisp.
SP.L: Anno seuentie one,
And Romelio is thirty eight: by that reckoning,
You were a Bawd at eight yeare old: now verily,
You fell to the Trade betimes.

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.L: There ya're from the Byas.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: I doe not know my age directly; sure I am elder,
I can remember two great frosts, and three great plagues,
And the losse of Callis, and the first comming vp
Of the Breeches with the great Codpiece,
And I pray what age doe you take me of then?

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.L: Well come off agen.

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.L: An old hunted Hare, she has all her doubles.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: For your owne grauities,
And the reuerence of the Court, I doe beseech you,
Rip vp the cause no further, but proceed to Sentence.

SP.SPEAKER: Crisp.
SP.L: One question more and I haue done:
Might not this Crispiano, this Spanyard,
Lye with your Mistris at some other time,
Either afore or after, then ith absence of her husband?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: Neuer.

SP.SPEAKER: Cris.
SP.L: Are you certaine of that?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: On my soule, neuer.

SP.SPEAKER: Cris.
SP.L: That's well he neuer lay with her,
But in anno seuenty one, let that be remembred.
Stand you aside a while. Mistris, the truth is,
I knew this Crispiano, liued in Naples
At the same time, and loued the Gentleman
As my bosome friend; and as I doe remember,
The Gentleman did leaue his Picture with you,
If age or neglect haue not in so long time ruin'd it.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: I preserue it still my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Cris.
SP.L: I pray let me see't, let me see the face
I then loued so much to looke on.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: Fetch it.

SP.SPEAKER: Win
SP.L: I shall, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Cris.
SP.L: No, no, Gentlewoman,
I haue other businesse for you.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Sur.
SP.L: Now were the time to cut Romelio's throat,
And accuse him for your murder.

SP.SPEAKER: Contar.
SP.L: By no meanes.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Sur.
SP.L: Will you not let vs be men of fashion,
And downe with him now hee's going?

SP.SPEAKER: Centar.
SP.L: Peace lets attend the sequell.

SP.SPEAKER: Cris
SP.L: I commend you Lady,
There was a maine matter of Conscience,
How many ills spring from Adultery!
First, the supreame Law that is violated,
Nobilitie oft stain'd with bastardy,
Inheritance of Land falsly possest,
The husband! corn'd, wife sham'd, and babes vnblest,
So, hang it vp i'th Court; you haue heard,
What has been vrged gainst Romelio.
Now my definitiue sentence in this cause,
Is, I will giue no sentence at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Ario.
SP.L: No?

SP.SPEAKER: Cris.
SP.L: No, I cannot, for I am made a partie.

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.L: How a party? here are fine crosse trickes,
What the deuill will he doe now?

SP.SPEAKER: Crisp.
SP.L: Signior Ariosto, his Maiestie of Spaine,
Conferres my Place vpon you by this Patent,
Which till this vrgent houre I haue kept
From your knowledge: may you thriue in't, noble sir,
And doe that which but few in our place doe,
Goe to their graue vncurst.

SP.SPEAKER: Ario.
SP.L: This Law businesse
Will leaue me so small leasure to serue God,
I shall serue the King the worse.

SP.SPEAKER: San
SP.L: Is hee a Iudge?
We must then looke for all Conscience, and no Law,
Heele begger all his followers.

SP.SPEAKER: Cris.
SP.L: Sir, I am of your Counsell, for the cause in hand
Was begun at such a time, fore you could speake;
You had need therefore haue one speake for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ario.
SP.L: Stay, I doe here first make protestation,
I nere tooke fee of this Romelio,
For being of his Councell, which may free me,
Being now his Iudge, for the imputation
Of taking a Bribe. Now sir, speake your mind.

SP.SPEAKER: Crisp.
SP.L: I do first intrear, that the eyes of all here present,
May be sixt vpon this

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: Oh, I am confounded. this is Crispiano.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul
SP.L: This is my father, how the Iudges haue bleated him.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: You may see truth will out in spite of the Deuill.

SP.SPEAKER: Cris.
SP.L: Behold, I am the shadow of this shadow,
Age has made me so; take from me fortie yeares,
And I was such a Summer fruit as this,
At least the Paynter sayned so: for indeed,
Painting and Epitaphs are both alike,
They slatter vs, and say we haue been thus:
But I am the partie here, that stands accused,
For Adultery with this woman, in the yeare
Seuentie one: now I call you my Lord to witnesse,
Foure yeares before that time, I went to'th Indies,
And till this month, did neuer set my foot since
In Europe; and for any former incontinence,
She has vowed there was neuer any: what remaines then,
But this is a meere practise 'gainst her sonne,
And I beseech the Court it may be sifted,
And most seuerely punisht.

SP.SPEAKER: San
SP.L: Vds foot, we are spoyled,
Why my Clyent's prooued an honest woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: What doe you thinke will become of me now?

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.L: You'l be made daunce achrimae I feare at a Carts

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.L: You Mistris, where are you now? (tayle.
Your Tennis court slips, and your tane drinke
In a morning for your hote liner; where's the man,
Would haue had some dealing with you, that you might
Keepe counsell the better.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: May it please the Court, I am but a yong thing,
And was drawne asie, varsie into the businesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Ario.
SP.L: How young? of fiue and fortie?

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: Fiue and fortie, and shall please you!
I am not fiue and twentie:
Shee made me colour my haire with Bean-flower,
To seeme older then I was; and then my rotten teeth,
With eating sweet-meats: why, should a Farrier
Looke in my mouth, he might mistake my age.
Oh Mistris, Mistris, you are an honest woman,
And you may be asham'd on't, to abuse the Court thus.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: Whatsoere I haue attempted,
Gainst my owne fame, or the reputation
Of that Gentleman my sonne, the Lord Contarino
Was cause of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Conta.
SP.L: Who I?

SP.SPEAKER: Ario.
SP.L: He that should haue married your daughter?
It was a plot belike then to conferre
The land on her that should haue bin his wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: More then I haue said already, all the world
Shall nere extract from me; I intreat from both,
Your equall pardons.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: And I from you sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Crisp.
SP.L: Sirrah, stand you aside,
I will talke with you hereafter.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: I could neuer away with after reckonings.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: And now my Lords, I doe most voluntarily
Confine my selfe vnto a stricter prison,
And a seuerer penance, then this Court can impose,
I am entred into Religion.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: I the cause of this practise; this vngodly woman,
Has sold her selfe to falshood: I wil now reueale my selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Erco.
SP.L: Stay my Lord here's a window
To let in more light to the Court.

SP.SPEAKER: Cont.
SP.L: Mercy vpon me! oh, that thou art liuing
Is mercy indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Sur.
SP.L: Stay, keepe in your shell a little longer?

SP.SPEAKER: Erco.
SP.L: I am Ercole.

SP.SPEAKER: Ario.
SP.L: A guard vpon him for the death of Contarino.

SP.SPEAKER: Erco.
SP.L: I obey the arrest o'th Court.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom
SP.L: Oh sir, you are happily restored to life,
And to vs your friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Erco.
SP.L: Away, thou art the Traytor:
I onely liue to challenge this former suite,
Toucht but thy fame, this accusation
Reaches to thy fame and life: the braue Contarino
Is generally supposed slaine by this hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: How knowes he the contrary?

SP.SPEAKER: Erc.
SP.L: But truth is,
Hauing receiued from me some certaine wounds,
Which were not mortall, this vild murderer,
Being by Will deputed Ouerseer
Of the Noblemans Estate, to his sisters vse,
That he might make him sure from suruiuing,
To reuoke that Will, stole to him in's bed, and kild him.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Strange, vnheard of, more practise yet!

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.L: What proofe of this?

SP.SPEAKER: Erco.
SP.L: The report of his mother deliuered to me,
In distraction for Contarino's death.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: For my death? I begin to apprehend,
That the violence of this womans loue to me,
Might practise the disinheriting of her sonne.

SP.SPEAKER: Ario.
SP.L: What say you to this Leonora?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: Such a thing I did vtter out of my distraction:
But how the Court will censure that report,
I leaue to their wisdomes.

SP.SPEAKER: Ario.
SP.L: My opinion is,
That this late slaunder vrged against her sonne,
Takes from her all manner of credit:
Shee that would not sticke to depriue him of his liuing,
Will as little tender his life.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: I beseech the Court,
I may retire my selfe to my place of pennance,
I haue vowed my selfe and my woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Ario.
SP.L: Goe when you please: what should moue you
Be thus forward in the accusation?

SP.SPEAKER: Erco.
SP.L: My loue to Contarino.

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.L: Oh, it bore very bitter fruit at your last meeting.

SP.SPEAKER: Erco.
SP.L: Tis true: but I begun to loue him,
When I had most cause to hate him, when our bloods
Embrac'd each other, then I pitied,
That so much valour should be hazarded
On the fortune of a single Rapier,
And not spent against the Turke.

SP.SPEAKER: Ario.
SP.L: Stay sir, be well aduised,
There is no testimony but your owne,
To approue you slew him, therefore no other way
To decide it, but by Duell.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Yes my Lord, I dare affirme gainst all the world,
This Noble man speakes truth.

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.L: You will make your selfe a party in the Duell.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Let him, I wil fight with thē both, sixteen of them.

SP.SPEAKER: Erco.
SP.L: Sir, I doe not know you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cont
SP.L: Yes but you haue forgot me, you and I haue sweat
In the Breach together at Malta.

SP.SPEAKER: Erco.
SP.L: Cry you me, I haue knowne of your Nation
Braue Souldiers.

SP.SPEAKER: Iulio
SP.L: Now if my father
Haue any true spirit in him, Ile recouer
His good opinion Doe you heare? doe not sweare sir,
For I dare sweare, that you will sweare a lye,
A very filthy, stinking. rotten lye:
And if the Lawyers thinke not this sufficient,
Ile giue the lye in the stomacke,
That's somewhat deeper then the throat;
Both here, and all France ouer and ouer,
From Marselys, or Bayon, to Callis Sands,
And there draw my Sword vpon thee,
And new scoure it in the grauell of thy kidneys.

SP.SPEAKER: Ari
SP.L: You the Defendant charged with the murder,
And you Second there,
Must be committed to the custody
Of the Knight-Marshall; and the Court giues charge,
They be to morrow ready in the Listes
Before the Sunne be rissen.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: I doe entreat the Court, there be a guard
Placed ore my Sister, that shee enter not
Into Religion: shee's rich my Lords,
And the perswasions of Fryers, to gaine
All her possessions to their Monasteries,
May doe much vpon her.

SP.SPEAKER: Ario.
SP.L: Weele take order for her.

SP.SPEAKER: Crisp
SP.L: There's a Nun too you haue got with child,
How will you dispose of her?

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: You question me, as if I were grau'd already,
When I haue quencht this wild-sire
In Ercoles tame blood, Ile tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: Erco.
SP.L: You haue iudged to day
A most confused practise, that takes end
In as bloody a tryall, and we may obserue
By these great persons, and their indirect
Proceedings, shaddowed in a vaile of State.
Mountaines are deformed heaps, sweld vp alofts
Vales wholsomer, though lower, and trod on oft.

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.L: Well, I will pu vp my papers,
And send them to France for a President,
That they may not say yet, but for one strange
Law suite, we come somewhat neere them.

SP.STAGE: Enter Iolenta, and Angiolella great bellied.

SP.SPEAKER: Iolen.
SP.L: How dost thou friend? welcome, thou and I.
Were play-fellowes together, little children,
So small awhile agoe, that I presume,
We are neither of vs wise yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Angi.
SP.L: A most sad truth on my part.

SP.SPEAKER: Iolen.
SP.L: Why doe you plucke your vaile
Ouer your face?

SP.SPEAKER: Angio.
SP.L: If you will beleeue truth,
There's nought more terrible to a guiltie heart,
As the eye of a respected friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Iol.
SP.L: Say friend, are you quicke with child?

SP.SPEAKER: Angi
SP.L: Too sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Iol.
SP.L: How could you know
Of your first child when you quicned?

SP.SPEAKER: Angio.
SP.L: How could you know friend?
Tis reported you are in the same taking.

SP.SPEAKER: Iolen.
SP.L: Ha, ha, ha, so tis giuen out:
But Ercoles comming to life againe, has shrunke,
And made innisible my great belly; ves faith,
My being with child was meerely in supposition,
Not practise.

SP.SPEAKER: Angio.
SP.L: You are happy, what would I giue,
To be a Mayd againe?

SP.SPEAKER: Iolen
SP.L: Would you, to what purpose?
I would neuer giue great purchase for that thing
Is in danger euery houre to be lost: pray thee laugh.
A Boy or a Girle for a wager?

SP.SPEAKER: Angio.
SP.L: What heauen please.

SP.SPEAKER: Jolen.
SP.L: Nay, nay, will you venter
A chaine of Pearle with me whether?

SP.SPEAKER: Angio.
SP.L: Ile lay nothing,
I haue ventur'd too much for't already, my fame.
I make no question sister, you haue heard
Of the intended combate.

SP.SPEAKER: Iolen.
SP.L: O what else?
I haue a sweet heart in't, against a brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Angio.
SP.L: And I a dead friend, I feare; what good counsell
Can you minister vnto me?

SP.SPEAKER: Iolen.
SP.L: Faith onely this,
Since there's no meanes i'th world to hinder it,
Let thou and I wench get as farre as we can
From the noyse of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Angio.
SP.L: Whither?

SP.SPEAKER: Iolen.
SP.L: No matter, any whither.

SP.SPEAKER: Angio.
SP.L: Any whither, so you goe not by sea:
I cannot abide rough water.

SP.SPEAKER: Iolen
SP.L: Not indure to be tumbled? say no more then,
Weele be land-Souldiers for that tricke: take heart,
Thy boy shall be borne a braue Roman.

SP.SPEAKER: Angio.
SP.L: O you meane to goe to Rome then.

SP.SPEAKER: Iol.
SP.L: Within there. Beare this Letter
To the Lord Ercole. Now wench, I am for thee
All the world ouer.

SP.SPEAKER: Angio.
SP.L: I like your shade pursue you.

SP.SPEAKER: Pros.
SP.L: Well, I do not thinke but to see you as pretty a
piece of Law-flesh.

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.L: In time I may,
Marry I am resolued to take a new way for't.
SP.P: You haue Lawyers take their Clients fees, & their backs are no sooner turn'd, but they call them fooles, and laugh at them.

SP.SPEAKER: Prosp.
SP.L: That's ill done of them.

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.L: There's one thing too that has a vild abuse in't.

SP.SPEAKER: Pro.
SP.L: What's that?

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.L: Marry this,
SP.P: That no Proctor in the Terme time be tollerated to go to the Tauerne aboue six times i'th forenoone.

SP.SPEAKER: Pros.
SP.L: Why man?

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.L: Oh sir, it makes their Clients ouertaken,
And become friends sooner then they would be.
SP.STAGE: Enter Ercole with a letter, and Contarino comming in Friers habits, as hauing bin at the Batha∣nites, a Ceremony vsed afore these Combates.

SP.SPEAKER: Erco.
SP.L: Leaue the Roome, Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Wherefore should I with such an obstinacy,
Conceale my selfe any longer. I am taught,
That all the blood which wil be shed to morrow,
Must fall vpon my head; one question
Shall fix it or vntie it: Noble brother,
I would faine know how it is possible,
When it appeares you loue the faire Iolenta
With such a height of feruor, you were ready
To father anothers child, and marry her,
You would so suddenly ingage your selfe,
To kill her brother, one that euer stood,
Your loyall and firme friend?

SP.SPEAKER: Erco.
SP.L: Sir, Ile tell you,
My loue, as I haue formerly protested
To Contarino, whose vnfortunate end,
The traytor wrought: and here is one thing more,
Deads all good thoughts of him, which I now receiu'd
From Iolenta.

SP.SPEAKER: Cont.
SP.L: In a Letter?

SP.SPEAKER: Erco.
SP.L: Yes, in this Letter:
For hauing sent to her to be resolued
Most truely, who was father of the child,
Shee writes backe, that the shame she goes withall,
Was begot by her brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Cont.
SP.L: O most incestious villaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Erc.
SP.L: I protest, before I thought 'twas Contarinos Issue,
And for that would haue vail'd her dishonour.

SP.SPEAKER: Cont.
SP.L: No more.
Has the Armorer brought the weapons?

SP.SPEAKER: Erco.
SP.L: Yes sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cont.
SP.L: I will no more thinke of her.

SP.SPEAKER: Erco.
SP.L: Of whom?

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Of my mother, I was thinking of my mother.
Call the Armorer.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: You doe loue me sir, you say?

SP.SPEAKER: Sur.
SP.L: O most intirely.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: And you will marry me?

SP.SPEAKER: Sur
SP.L: Nay, Ile doe more then that.
The fashion of the world is many times,
To make a woman naught, and afterwards
To marry her: but I a'th contrary,
SP.P: Will make you honest first, and afterwards Proceed to the wedlocke.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: Honest, what meane you by that?

SP.SPEAKER: Sur.
SP.L: I meane, that your suborning the late Law-suite,
Has got you a filthy report: now there's no way,
But to doe some excellent piece of honesty,
To recouer your good name.

SP.SPEAKER: Win
SP.L: How sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Sur.
SP.L: You shall straight goe, and reueale to your old
Mistris, for certaine truth, Contarino is aliue.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: How, liuing?

SP.SPEAKER: Sur.
SP.L: Yes, he is liuing.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: No, I must not tell her of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sur.
SP.L: No, why?

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: For shee did bind me yesterday by oath,
Neuer more to speake of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sur.
SP.L: You shall reueale it then to Ariosto the Iudge.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: By no meanes, he has heard me
Tell so many lyes ith Court, hee'l nere beleeue mee.
What if I told it to the Capuchin?

SP.SPEAKER: Sur.
SP.L: You cannot think of a better; for as your yong Mris.
Who as you told me, has perswaded you,
To runne away with her: let her haue her humour.
I haue a suite Romelio left I'th house,
The habit of a Iew, that Ile put on,
And pretending I am robb'd, by breake of day,
Procure all Passengers to be brought backe,
And by the way reueale my selfe, and discouer
The Commicall euent. They say shee's a little mad,
This will helpe to cure her: goe, goe presently,
And reueale it to the Capuchin.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: Sir, I shall

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.P: A pox ont, I haue vndertaken the challenge very foolishly: what if I doe not appeare to answer it?

SP.SPEAKER: Pro.
SP.L: It would be absolute conuiction
Of Cowardice, and Periury; and the Dane,
May to your publike shame, reuerse your Armes,
Or haue them ignomiously fastned
Vnder his horse tayle.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: I doe not like that so well.
I see then I must fight whether I will or no.

SP.SPEAKER: Prosp.
SP.L: How does Romelio beare himselfe? They say,
He has almost brain'd one of our cunningst Fencers,
That practisd with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: Very certaine; and now you talke of fencing,
Doe not you remember the Welsh Gentleman,
That was trauailing to Rome vpon returne?

SP.SPEAKER: Pros.
SP.L: No, what of him?

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: There was a strange experiment of a Fencer.

SP.SPEAKER: Pras.
SP.L: What was that?

SP.SPEAKER: Jul
SP.L: The Welshman in's play, do what the Fencer could,
Hung still an arse; he could not for's life
Make him come on brauely: till one night at supper,
Obseruing what a deale of Parma cheese
His Scholler deuoured, goes ingeniously
The next morning, and makes a spacious button
For his foyle of tosted cheese, and as sure as you liue,
That made him come on the braueliest.

SP.SPEAKER: Pros.
SP.L: Possible!

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: Marry it taught him an ill grace in's play,
It made him gape still, gape as he put in for't,
As I haue seene some hungry Vsher.

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.L: The tosting of it belike,
Was to make it more supple, had he chanc'd
To haue hit him a'th chaps.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: Not vnlikely. Who can tell me,
If we may breath in the Duell?

SP.SPEAKER: Pro.
SP.L: By no meanes.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: Nor drinke?

SP.SPEAKER: Pros.
SP.L: Neither.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: That's scuruy, anger will make me very dry.

SP.SPEAKER: Pros.
SP.L: You mistake sir, tis sorrow that is very dry.

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.L: Not alwayes sir, I haue knowne sorrow very wet.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: In rainy weather.

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.L: No, when a woman has come dropping wet
Out of a Cuckingstoole.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: Then twas wet indeed sir.
SP.STAGE: Enter Romelio very melancholly, and the Capuchin.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: Hauing from Leonoras Wayting-woman,
Deliuer'd a most strange Intelligence
Of Contarino's recouery, I am come
To sound Romelio's penitence; that perform'd,
To end these errours by discouering,
What shee related to me. Peace to you sir,
Pray Gentlemen, let the freedome of this Roome
Be mine a little. Nay sir, you may stay.
Will you pray with me?

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: No, no, the world and I
Haue not made vp our accounts yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: Shall I pray for you?

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Whether you doe or no, I care not.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: O you haue a dangerous voyage to take.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: No matter, I will be mine owne Pilot:
Doe not you trouble your head with the businesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: Pray tell me, do not you meditate of death?

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Phew, I tooke out that Lesson,
When I once lay sicke of an Ague: I doe now
Labour for life, for life. Sir, can you tell me,
Whether your Tolledo, or your Millain Blade
Be best temper'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: These things you know, are out of my practice.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: But these are things you know,
I must practice with to morrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: Were I in your case,
I should present to my selfe strange shaddowes.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Turne you, were I in your case,
I should laugh at mine one shadow.
Who has hired you to make me Coward?

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: I would make you a good Christian.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom
SP.L: Withall, let me continue
An honest man, which I am very certaine,
A coward can neuer be; you take vpon you
A Phisicians place, rather then a Diuines.
You goe about to bring my body so low,
I should sight i'th Lists to morrow like a Dormouse,
And be made away in a slumber.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: Did you murder Contarino?

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: That's a scuruy question now.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: Why sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Did you aske it as a Confessor, or as a spie?

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: As one that faine would iustle the deuill
Out of your way.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Vm, you are but weakly made for't:
SP.P: Hee's a cunning wrastler, I can tell you, and has broke many a mans necke.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: But to giue him the foyle, goes not by strength.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Let it goe by what it will,
Get me some good victuals to breakfast, I am hungry.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: Here's food for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Pew, I am not to commence Doctor:
For then the word, Deuoure that booke, were proper.
I am to sight, to sight sir, and Ile doo't,
As I would feed, with a good stomacke.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: Can you feed, and apprehend death?

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Why sir? Is not Death
A hungry companion? Say? is not the graue
Said to be a great deuourer? Get me some victuals.
I knew a man that was to loose his head,
Feed with an excellent good appetite,
To strengthen his heart, scarce halfe an houre before.
And if he did it, that onely was to speake,
What should I, that am to doe?

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: This confidence,
If it be grounded vpon truth, tis well.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: You must vnderstand, that Resolution
Should euer wayt vpon a noble death,
As Captaines bring their Souldiers out o'th field,
And come off last: for, I pray what is death?
The safest Trench i'th world to keepe man free
From Fortunes Gunshot; to be afraid of that,
Would proue me weaker then a teeming woman,
That does indure a thousand times more paine
In bearing of a child.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap
SP.L: O, I tremble for you:
For I doe know you haue a storme within you,
More terrible then a Sea-fight, and your soule
Being heretofore drown'd in securitie,
You know not how to liue, nor how to dye:
But I haue an obiect that shall startle you,
And make you know whither you are going.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: I am arm'd for't.
SP.STAGE: Enter Leonora with two Coffins borne by her seruants, and two Winding-sheets stucke with flowers, presents one to her sonne, and the other to Iulio.
SP.L: Tis very welcome, this is a decent garment
Will neuer be out of fashion. I will kisse it.
All the Flowers of the Spring,
Meet to perfume our burying:
These haue but their growing prime,
And man does slourish but his time.
Suruey our progresse from our birth,
We are set, we grow, we turne to earth.
Courts adieu, and all delights,
All bewitching appetites;
Sweetest Breath, and clearest eye,
Like perfumes goe out and dye;
And consequently this is done,
As shadowes wait vpon the Sunne.
Vaine the ambition of Kings,
Who seeke by trophies and dead things,
To leaue a liuing name behind
And weaue but nets to catch the wind:
O you haue wrought a myracle, and melted
A heart of Adamant, you haue compris'd
In this dumbe Pageant, a right excellent forme
Of penitence.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: I am glad you so receiue it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ro.
SP.L: This obiect does perswade me to forgiue
The wrong she has don me, which I count the way
To be forgiuen yonder: and this Shrowd
Shewes me how rankly we doe smel of earth,
When we are in all our glory. Will it please you
Enter that Closet, where I shall confer
Bout matters of most waightie consequence,
Before the Duell.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul
SP.L: Now I am right in the Bandileere for th' gallows.
What a scuruy fashion tis, to hang ones coffin in a scarfe?

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: Why this is well:
And now that I haue made you fit for death,
And brought you euen as low as is the graue,
I will raise you vp agen speake comforts to you
Beyond your hopes, turne this intended Duell
To a triumph.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: More Diuinitie yet?
Good sir, doe one thing first, there's in my Closet
A Prayer booke that is couer'd with guilt Vellom,
Fetch it, and pray you certifie my mother,
Ile presently come to her.
So now you are safe.

SP.SPEAKER: Jul.
SP.L: What haue you done?

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Why I haue lockt them vp
Into a Turret of the Castle safe enough,
For troubling vs this foure houres; and he please,
He may open a Casement, and whistle out to'th Sea,
Like a Boson, not any creature can heare him.
Wast not thou a weary of his preaching?

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: Yes, if he had had an houre-glasse by him,
I would haue wisht him he would haue ioggd it a little.
But your mother, your mother's lockt in to.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: So much the better,
I am rid of her howling at parting.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: Harke, he knocks to be let out and he were mad.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Let him knocke till his Sandals flie in pieces.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: Ha, what sayes he? Contarino liuing?

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: I, I, he meanes he would haue Contarino's liuing
Bestowed vpon his Monastery, 'tis that
He onely fishes for. So, 'tis breake of day,
We shall be call'd to the combate presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: I am sory for one thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: What's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: That I made not mine owne Ballad: I doe feare
I shall be roguishly abused in Meeter,
If I miscarry. Well, if the young Capuchin
Doe not talke a'th flesh as fast now to your mother,
As he did to vs a'th spirit; if he doe,
Tis not the first time that the prison royall
Has been guiltie of close committing.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Now to'th Combate.
SP.STAGE: Enter Capuchin and Leonora aboue at a window.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.L: Contarino liuing?

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: Yes Madam, he is liuing, and Ercoles Second.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: Why has he lockt vs vp thus?

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: Some euill Angell
Makes him deafe to his owne safetie, we are shut
Into a Turret, the most desolate prison
Of all the Castle, and his obstinacy,
Madnesse, or secret fate, has thus preuented,
The sauing of his life.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: Oh the sauing Contarino's,
His is worth nothing: for heauens sake call lowder.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: To little purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: I will leape these Battlements,
And may I be found dead time enough,
To hinder the combate.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: Oh looke vpwards rather,
Their deliuerance must come thence: to see how heauen,
Can inuert mans firmest purpose: his intent
Of murthering Contarino, was a meane
To worke his safety, and my comming hither
To saue him, is his ruine: wretches turne
The tide of their good fortune, and being drencht
In some presumptuous and hidden sinnes,
While they aspire to doe themselues most right,
The deuil that rules ith ay re, hangs in their light.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Oh they must not be lost thus; some good christian come within our hearing: ope the other casement that looks into the citie.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: Madam, I shall.

SP.STAGE: The Lists set vp. Enter the Marshall, Crispiano, and Ariosto as Iudges, they sit.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.L: Giue the Appealant his Summons, doe the like
To the Defendant.
SP.STAGE: Enter at one doore, Ercole and Contarino, at the other, Romelio and Julio.
SP.L: Can any of you alledge ought, why the Combate
Should not proceed?

SP.SPEAKER: Combatants.
SP.L: Nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Ario
SP.L: Haue the Knights weighed,
And measured their weapons?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.L: They haue.

SP.SPEAKER: Ario.
SP.L: Proceed then to the battell, and may heauen
Determine the right.

SP.SPEAKER: Herauld.
SP.L: Soit le Battaile, et Victory a ceux que droit.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom
SP.L: Stay, I doe not well know whither I am going:
'Twere needfull therefore, though at the last gaspe,
To haue some Church mans prayer. Run I pray thee,
To Castle Nouo; this key will release
A Capuchin and my mother, whom I shut
Into a Turret, bid them make hast, and pray
I may be dead ere he comes. Now, Victory a ceux que droit.
SP.STAGE: All the Champ. Victory a ccux que droit.
The Combate continued to a good length, when enters Leonora, and the Capuchin.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.L: Hold, hold, for heauens sake hold.

SP.SPEAKER: Ari.
SP.L: What are these that interrupt the combate?
Away to prison with them.

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: We haue been prisoners too long:
Oh sir, what meane you? Contarino's liuing.

SP.SPEAKER: Erco.
SP.L: Liuing!

SP.SPEAKER: Cap.
SP.L: Behold him liuing.

SP.SPEAKER: Erco.
SP.L: You were but now my second, now I make you
My selfe for euer.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.L: Oh here's one betweene,
Claimes to be neerer.

SP.SPEAKER: Cont.
SP.L: And to you deare Lady,
I haue entirely vowed my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: If I doe not dreame, I am happy to.

SP.SPEAKER: Ario.
SP.L: How insolently has this high Court of Honor
Beene abused!

SP.STAGE: Enter Angiolella vail'd, and Iolenta, her face colour'd like a Moore, the two Surgeons, one of them like a Iew.

SP.SPEAKER: Ario.
SP.L: How now, who are these?

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Sur.
SP.L: A couple of strange Fowle, and I the Falconer,
That haue sprung them. This is a white Nun,
Of the Order of Saint Clare; and this a blacke one,
Youle take my word for't.

SP.SPEAKER: Ario.
SP.L: Shee's a blacke one indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Jolen.
SP.L: Like or dislike me, choose you whether,
The Downe vpon the Rauens feather,
Is as gentle and as sleeke,
As the Mole on Uenus cheeke.
Hence vaine shew, I onely care,
To preserue my Soule most faire.
Neuer mind the outward skin,
But the Iewell that's within:
And though I want the crimson blood,
Angels boast my Sister-hood.
Which of vs now iudge you whiter,
Her whose credit proues the lighter,
Or this blacke, and Ebon hew,
That vnstain'd, keeps fresh and true:
For I proclaim't without controle,
There's no true beauty, but ith Soule.

SP.SPEAKER: Erco.
SP.L: Oh tis the faire Iolenta; to what purpose
Are you thus ecclipst?

SP.SPEAKER: Iol
SP.L: Sir, I was running away
From the rumour of this Combate: I fled likewise,
From the vntrue report my brother spread
To his politike ends, that I was got with child.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.L: Cease here all further scruteny, this paper
Shall giue vnto the Court each circumstance,
Of all these passages.

SP.SPEAKER: Ario.
SP.L: No more: attend the Sentence of the Court.
Rarenesse and difficultie giue estimation
To all things are i'th world: you haue met both
In these seuerall passages: now it does remaine,
That these so Comicall euents be blasted
With no seueritie of Sentence: You Romelio,
Shall first deliuer to that Gentleman,
Who stood your Second, all those Obligations,
Wherein he stands engaged to you,
Receiuing onely the principall.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: I shall my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Iul.
SP.L: I thanke you,
I haue an humour now to goe to Sea
Against the Pyrats; and my onely ambition,
Is to haue my Ship furnisht with a rare consort
Of Musicke; and when I am pleased to be mad,
They shall play me Orlando.

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.L: You muft lay wait for the Fidlers,
Theyle flye away from the presse like Watermen.

SP.SPEAKER: Ario.
SP.L: Next, you shall marry that Nun.

SP.SPEAKER: Rom.
SP.L: Most willingly.

SP.SPEAKER: Angio.
SP.L: Oh sir, you haue been vnkind;
But I doe onely wish, that this my shame,
May warne all honest Virgins, not to seeke
The way to Heauen, that is so wondrous steepe,
Through those vowes they are too fraile to keepe.

SP.SPEAKER: Ario.
SP.L: Contarino, and Romelio, and your selfe,
Shall for seuen yeares maintaine against the Turke,
Six Gallies. Leonora, Iolenta,
And Angiolella there the beautious Nun,
For their vowes breach vnto the Monastery,
Shall build a Monastery. Lastly, the two Surgeons,
For concealing Contarino s recouery,
Shall exercise their Art at their owne charge,
For a tweluemonth in the Gallies: so we leaue you,
Wishing your future life may make good vse
Of these euents, since that these passages,
Which threatned ruine, built on rotten ground,
Are with successe beyond our wishes crown'd.
